member.name: T:Snap.Color
member.summary: Provides functions to relate NX and Windows colors

member.name: M:Snap.Color.WindowsColor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Returns the System.Drawing.Color corresponding to a given NX color index
member.param: An index into the color table of the work part
member.remarks: The color index should be between 1 and 216.
member.example: This example shows how to get the System.Drawing.Color corresponding to a given NX color index:

member.name: M:Snap.Color.ColorIndex(System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Returns the index of the NX color most closely matching a given System.Drawing.Color
member.returns: The index of the closest color in the work part

remarks.para: This function returns an index from the color table of the work part, choosing the color that's closest to the given Windows color. Since the color table has only 216 entries, it's quite likely that the NX color will not match the given Windows color exactly.

member.example: This example shows how to get the NX color index most closely matching a given System.Drawing.Color:

member.name: M:Snap.Color.NXColor(System.Drawing.Color)
member.summary: Returns the NX color most closely matching a given System.Drawing.Color
member.returns: The closest NXOpen.NXColor in the work part

remarks.para: This function returns a color from the color table of the work part, choosing the one that's closest to the given Windows color. Since the color table has only 216 entries, it's quite likely that the NX color will not match the given Windows color exactly.

member.example: This example shows how to get the NX color most closely matching a given System.Drawing.Color

member.name: T:Snap.Draw
member.summary: Provides functions for drawing temporary graphics in the NX window.

remarks.para: Drawing temporary graphics is useful when you want to provide information or feedback to the user of your programs. The graphics are erased if the user explicitly chooses the "Refresh" function, or uses some other function that involves refreshing the display.
Drawing temporary graphics is often much faster than creating (and deleting) NX curves, and the display is easy for the user to erase when it's no longer needed.

member.name: M:Snap.Draw.DrawMarker(Snap.NX.View,Snap.Position,System.Drawing.Color,Snap.Draw.Marker)
member.summary: Draws a temporary marker (a SNAP Marker) in the specified view
member.param: The view in which the marker should be displayed
The position where the marker should be displayed
The desired color of the marker
The type of marker to display (SNAP marker)

remarks.para:
This function uses SNAP markers, which are just a limited set of the most common and useful ones. If you need access to a broader set of markers, please use the other
Snap.Draw.DrawMarker function.

member.example: The following example draws some markers and a polyline

member.param: The view in which the marker should be displayed

The desired color of the marker
The type of marker to display (NX Open marker)

member.name: M:Snap.Draw.DrawText(Snap.NX.View,System.Drawing.Color,Snap.Position,System.String[])
member.summary: Draws temporary text in the specified view
member.param: The view in which the text should be drawn
An array of lines of text

remarks.para: The text is drawn using the default system font at a "medium" size. The text has a fixed size when measured in pixels, so, as you zoom in and out, the text will remain the same size. Also, the text will remain parallel to the plane of the screen as you rotate the view. So, in short, the text looks and behaves like the text used to label the WCS axes in NX.
The location specified is the left-hand end of the baseline of the first line of text.

member.example: This example shows how to draw temporary text:

member.name: P:Snap.Globals.Translucency
member.summary: The translucency value to be assigned to newly-created objects

remarks.para: The translucency value is an integer between 0 and 100. A value of 0 indicates that the object is completely opaque (no translucency at all). A value of 100 indicates that the object is completely translucent, and therefore invisible.
The translucency setting affects any bodies (solids or sheets) or facetted bodies that are created subsequently.

If UnitType = Inch, then InchesPerUnit = 1.

member.name: P:Snap.Globals.DistanceTolerance
member.summary: Distance tolerance

remarks.para: This distance tolerance is the same one that you access via Preferences → Modeling Preferences in interactive NX. In many functions in NX, an approximation process is used to construct geometry (curves or bodies). The distance tolerance (together with the angle tolerance) controls the accuracy of this approximation, unless you specify some over-riding tolerance within the function itself. For example, when you offset a curve, NX will construct a spline curve that approximates the true offset to within the current distance tolerance.

member.name: P:Snap.Globals.AngleTolerance
member.summary: Angle tolerance, in degrees

remarks.para: This angle tolerance is the same one that you access via Preference → Modeling Preferences in interactive NX. In many functions in NX, an approximation process is used to construct geometry (curves or bodies). The angle tolerance (together with the distance tolerance) controls the accuracy of this approximation, unless you specify some over-riding tolerance within the function itself. For example, when you create a Through Curve Mesh feature in NX, the resulting surface will match the input curves to within the current distance and angle tolerances.
The angle tolerance is expressed in degrees.

member.name: P:Snap.Globals.ChainingTolerance
member.summary: The chaining tolerance used in building "section" objects

remarks.para: Most modeling features seem to set this internally to 0.95*DistanceTolerance, so that's what we use here.

To create features in SNAP code, you must first set HistoryMode to True.

member.name: M:Snap.Globals.SetUndoMark(Snap.Globals.MarkVisibility,System.String)
member.summary: Creates an Undo mark
member.param: Indicates the visibility of the undo mark
The name to be assigned to the Undo mark
member.returns: The ID of the newly created Undo mark

remarks.para: Creating an Undo mark gives you a way to save the state of the NX session. Then, at some later time, you can "roll back" to the Undo mark to restore NX to the saved state. This is useful for error recovery, and for reversing any temporary changes you have made (such as creation of temporary objects).
If you create a visible Undo mark, the name you assign will be shown in the Undo List on the NX Edit menu.
Please refer to the NX/Open Programmer's Guide for more information about Undo marks.

member.example: This example shows how to use Undo marks:

member.name: M:Snap.Globals.DeleteUndoMark(Snap.Globals.UndoMarkId,System.String)
member.summary: Deletes an Undo mark
member.param: The ID of the Undo mark
The name of the Undo mark.

remarks.para: You can access an Undo mark either using its ID or its name. The system will try to find the mark using the given ID, first. If this fails (because you have provided an incorrect ID), the system will try again to find the mark based on its name.

member.example: This example shows how to use Undo marks:

member.name: M:Snap.Globals.UndoToMark(Snap.Globals.UndoMarkId,System.String)
member.summary: Roll back to an existing Undo mark
member.param: The ID of the Undo mark to roll back to
The name of the Undo mark.

remarks.para: You can access an Undo mark either using its ID or its name. The system will try to find the mark using the given ID, first. If this fails (because you have provided an incorrect ID), the system will try again to find the mark based on its name.

member.example: This example shows how to use Undo marks:

member.name: T:Snap.Globals.MarkVisibility
member.summary: Indicates the visibility of an Undo mark

remarks.para: If an Undo mark is visible, its name will be shown in the Undo List on the NX Edit menu.

If an Undo mark is invisible, it will not be shown in the Undo List. An invisible Undo mark is typically used to save a "safe" state of the NX session that your code can then restore if some problem arises.

member.summary: Visible

member.summary: An identifier used to refer to an Undo mark

member.name: T:Snap.Number
member.summary: Class to allow either double or string inputs when creating features

remarks.para: When creating features, it is often useful to allow either Double or String values as function inputs. Rather than having two separate feature creation functions (one with Double inputs and one with String inputs), we typically have just a single function that uses Number objects as inputs. Since a Double or a String can be implicitly converted to a Number, this single function can accept either data type as input.

member.name: M:Snap.Number.ToString
member.summary: Produces a string representation of a Number object

remarks.para: The string representation is in either fixed-point or scientific (exponential) form, whichever is more compact, and with the decimal point represented by a period symbol.

member.name: M:Snap.Number.#ctor(System.Double)
member.summary: Creates a Number from a given double

member.name: M:Snap.Number.#ctor(System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a Number from a given integer

member.name: M:Snap.Number.#ctor(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a Number from a given double

remarks.para: In feature creation the Number is used as the right-hand side of an expression, so the string input here must be something that makes sense in this role.

member.name: M:Snap.Number.NullToZero(Snap.Number)
member.summary: Returns Number.Zero if the Number is Nothing

remarks.para: There are some places where we would like to use Number.Zero as the default value of an optional function argument. But we can't use Number.Zero as a default value, since it is not a compile-time constant, so we use Nothing, instead. This means (by convention) that the numerical value should be zero, by default. So then we need some standard way to convert Nothing to Number.Zero. That's what this function does.

member.name: M:Snap.Number.op_Implicit(System.Double)~Snap.Number
member.summary: Implicit conversion of double to Number (allows doubles to be used as inputs when creating features)

member.name: M:Snap.Number.op_Implicit(System.String)~Snap.Number
member.summary: Implicit conversion of string to Number (allows strings to be used as inputs when creating features)

member.name: M:Snap.Number.op_Implicit(System.Int32)~Snap.Number
member.summary: Implicit conversion of integer to Number (allows integer to be used as inputs when creating features)

member.name: F:Snap.Number.Zero
member.summary: The Number representing zero

member.summary: Convert number to string
member.returns: String using dot as decimal separator

member.name: M:Snap.Number.Parse(System.String)
member.summary: Convert string to number
member.returns: Double using dot as decimal separator

member.summary: Provides functions to support printing

member.name: M:Snap.Print.PrintDisplay(System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,NXOpen.PrintBuilder.OutputOption,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,System.Boolean,NXOpen.PrintBuilder.ImageResolutionOption,NXOpen.PrintBuilder.OrientationOption,NXOpen.PrintBuilder.PaperSize)
member.summary: Printing the Current Display
member.param: The number of copies to be printed. Optional. Default = 1
The thin width scale factor. See remarks below. This number cannot be less than 0.0. Optional. Default = 1.0
The normal width scale factor. See remarks below. This number cannot be less than 0.0. Optional. Default = 2.0
The thick width scale factor. See remarks below. This number cannot be less than 0.0. Optional. Default = 3.0
The type of output desired (shaded or wire-fame). Optional. Default = WireframeBlackWhite

If true, outputs an image with a white background, rather than using the current NX background color(s). This option is only applicable when the "output" parameter is set to "shaded". Optional. Default = False
If true, indicates that any raster images inserted in drawings will be output when printing. Optional. Default = True
The shaded geometry as wireframe option. If true, indicates that shaded objects will be printed as wireframes, rather than shaded. Optional. Default = False
The resolution of images created for printing shaded views. Optional. Default = Draft
The orientation of the printed page. Optional. Default = Landscape
The paper size used for printing. Optional. Default = A4

remarks.para: The basic line width is roughly 0.5 points. The thinWidth, normalWidth and thickWidth factors express line widths as multiples of this basic width. So, for example, if thinWidth = 3, then any line that has been designated as "thin" in NX will be printed with a width of roughly 1.5 points.

member.name: T:Snap.UnloadOption
member.summary: Indicates when you want the system to unload your application library from a running NX session.

remarks.para: This enum is exactly equivalent to NXOpen.Session.LibraryUnloadOption.

To use it, you should implement a static function called GetUnloadOption in the same class or module as the "Main" function of your application, as shown in the example below. NX will call this function to determine how it should unload your application library.
The GetUnloadOption function is not needed when running an application from the NX Journal Editor. In this scenario, the "Immediately" setting is always used.
If you base your application on a SNAP template in Visual Studio, then you don't have to write the GetUnloadOption function, because the template already includes it.

member.example: This example shows how to use the UnloadOption enum:

member.name: F:Snap.UnloadOption.Immediately
member.summary: You want the system to unload the library as soon as your application program has finished running.

remarks.para: This setting is very convenient when you are developing and debugging your application. But loading and unloading the library takes a little time, so this may not be suitable for an application that is finished and being used in production.
If your application is using the Show() method to display a winform, then it should not use the Immediately setting, since this will cause the winform to disappear immediately after it is displayed.

member.name: F:Snap.UnloadOption.Explicitly
member.summary: You will unload the library yourself, using the "Unload Shared Image" command in File-->Utilities.

member.name: F:Snap.UnloadOption.AtTermination
member.summary: You want the system to unload the library when the current NX session terminates.

remarks.para: This is usually the best setting for an application that is being used in production. It enhances performance (though usually only slightly) because your application is loaded into memory only once, regardless of how many times it is executed.
The AtTermination setting is used as the default if you do not provide a GetUnloadOption function.

member.name: M:Snap.Create.BezierCurveFit(Snap.Create.CurvePositionFunction,System.Object,System.Int32)
member.summary: Bezier approximation of a curve given by a function
member.param: Evaluator function that returns positions on curve
Data to be passed when calling evaluator function
member.returns: Degree m Bezier curve approximating the given function

remarks.para: To approximate a given curve, you could just create points on it, and then create a spline curve through those points. However, the distribution of the points can significantly impact the quality of the approximation. The approach used here frees you from the responsibility of choosing a good point distribution. To use this approach, you must provide a function that returns a position at a given parameter value on the curve you want to approximate.

member.example:
This example shows how to create a Bezier curve that approximates a special curve called a catenary:
This example shows how to create a Bezier curve that approximates an offset curve:
The following picture shows the results of the program:

remarks.para: You use a CurvePositionFunction when constructing approximating curves using the BezierCurveFit function.

The mu+1 u-values (nodes) at which to interpolate
The mv+1 v-values (nodes) at which to interpolate

remarks.para: The points are interpolated at the given node values. Specifically, the surface passes through the point intPoints[i,j] at the parameter values (u, v) = ( nodesU[i], nodesV[j] ).

A 2D array of nu x nv weights
Knots for u-direction -- an array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
Knots for v-direction -- an array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , v[nv+kv-1]
member.returns: A NX.Bsurface object, which is a body having a single face.

remarks.para: For further details, please see the documentation for the NX.Bsurface object.

member.summary: Constructs a polynomial b-surface from poles and knot sequences
member.param: A 2D array of nu x nv 3D poles
Knots for u-direction -- an array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
Knots for v-direction -- an array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , v[nv+kv-1]
member.returns: A NX.Bsurface object, which is a body having a single face.

member.name: M:Snap.Create.BsurfaceThroughPoints(Snap.Position[0:,0:],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Creates a Bsurface interpolating (passing through) a given array of points
member.param: An nu x nv array of points to be interpolated
The nu parameter u-values (nodes) at which to interpolate
The nv parameter v-values (nodes) at which to interpolate
Knots for u-direction -- an array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
Knots for v-direction -- an array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , v[nv+kv-1]
member.returns: A Bsurface interpolating the given points at the given (u,v) values

remarks.para: To use this function, you have to be somewhat familiar with b-spline technology, so it is not intended for beginners. If you've never heard of nodes or knots, and you don't know how to choose reasonable values for them, you should use the simpler version of BsurfaceThroughPoints, which does require you to specify nodes and knots.

member.example:
This example shows how to create a Bsurface:
The following picture shows the result of the example:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.BsurfaceThroughPoints(Snap.Position[0:,0:],System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a Bsurface interpolating (passing through) a given array of points
member.param: An nu x nv array of points to be interpolated
The degree of the desired surface in the u-direction
The degree of the desired surface in the v-direction
member.returns: A Snap.NX.Bsurface object passing through the given points
member.remarks:
For most purposes, a surface of degree 3×3 works fine.
If we denote the intPoints array by q, for brevity, then ...
The points q[0,0], q[0,1], ... ,q[0,nv] will lie along edge u = 0 (0 < v < 1)
The points q[0,0], q[1,0], ... ,q[nu,0] will lie along edge v = 0 (0 < u < 1)
So, in particular, if S(u,v) denotes the surface position at parameters u,v, then
S(0,0) = q[0,0] =
S(0,1) = q[0,nv] =
S(1,0) = q[nu,0] =
S(1,1) = q[nu,nv] =
member.example:
The following example creates a b-surface through points:
The following picture shows the result of the example:

Layers to be placed into the category

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Chamfer(Snap.NX.Edge,Snap.Number,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates a symmetric Snap.NX.Chamfer feature with a given offset distance
member.param: The offsetting method used (see remarks below)

remarks.para:
The offsetFaces parameter indicates the offsetting method used to determine the size of the chamfer.
If true, the edges of the chamfer face will be constructed by offsetting the faces adjacent to the selected edge
If false, the edges of the chamfer face will be constructed by offsetting the selected edge along the adjacent faces

member.example: This example shows how to chamfer an edge:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Chamfer(Snap.NX.Edge,Snap.Number,Snap.Number,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an asymmetric Snap.NX.Chamfer feature using two given offset distances
member.param: The offsetting method used (see remarks below)

remarks.para:
The offsetFaces parameter indicates the offsetting method used to determine the size of the chamfer
If true, the edges of the chamfer face will be constructed by offsetting the faces adjacent to the selected edge
If false, the edges of the chamfer face will be constructed by offsetting the selected edge along the adjacent faces

member.example: This example shows how to chamfer an edge:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Extrude(Snap.NX.ICurve[],Snap.Vector,Snap.Number[],Snap.Number)
member.summary: Creates a Snap.NX.Extrude feature using extrusion extents
member.param: The curves (or edges) to be extruded
Extents of the extrusion (measured from input curves)
Draft angle, in degrees. Optional. Default = Nothing, which gives a value of zero.

remarks.para: The type of body created will depend on whether or not the curve array is closed. A closed curve array will produce a solid body, and an open curve array will produce a sheet body. To force creation of a sheet body, please use the ExtrudeSheet functions.
If the draft angle is positive, the cross-sectional shape will grow smaller as you travel in the direction of the axis vector.

member.example: The following example shows how to create extruded features:

member.param: The curves (or edges) to be extruded
Length of the extrusion (measured from input curves)
Draft angle, in degrees. Optional. Default = Nothing, which gives a value of zero.

remarks.para: The type of body created will depend on whether or not the curve array is closed. A closed curve array will produce a solid body, and an open curve array will produce a sheet body. To force creation of a sheet body, please use the ExtrudeSheet functions.
If the draft angle is positive, the cross-sectional shape will grow smaller as you travel in the direction of the axis vector.

member.example: The following example shows how to create extruded features:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.ExtrudeSheet(Snap.NX.ICurve[],Snap.Vector,Snap.Number[],Snap.Number)

member.param: The curves (or edges) to be extruded
Extents of the extrusion (measured from input curves)
Draft angle, in degrees. Optional. Default = Nothing, which gives a value of zero.

remarks.para: This function always produces a sheet body. To create a solid body, please use the Extrude functions.
If the draft angle is positive, the cross-sectional shape will grow smaller as you travel in the direction of the axis vector.

member.example: The following example shows how to create extruded sheet features:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.ExtrudeShell(Snap.NX.ICurve[],Snap.Vector,Snap.Number[],Snap.Number[],Snap.Number)
member.summary: Creates a thin-walled shell type of Snap.NX.Extrude feature
member.param: The curves (or edges) to be extruded
Extents of the extrusion (measured from input curves)
Offset distances controlling the wall thickness of the shell
Draft angle, in degrees. Optional. Default = Nothing, which gives a value of zero.

remarks.para: Conceptually, this function sweeps the input curves to form a sheet body, and then thickens this sheet body to form a solid. The offset distances control the thickening process.
If the draft angle is positive, the cross-sectional shape will grow smaller as you travel in the direction of the axis vector.

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Isocline(Snap.NX.Face,Snap.Vector,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates isocline curves on a given face
member.param: Face used to get isocline curves
The draft angle defining the isocline curves (in degrees)
member.example:
An isocline is a curve along which the face normal makes some constant angle with a given plane. In other words, it is a curve along which the "draft angle" is constant.
The reference plane from which the draft angle is measured is normal to the given reference vector. Some specific examples might help to clarify:
If draftAngle = 0, the isoclines are silhouette curves
If draftAngle = 90, then, at points on the isoclines, the face normal is in the same direction as the given reference vector
If draftAngle = -90, then, at points on the isoclines, the face normal is in the opposite direction to the given reference vector
The given draftAngle must be between -90 and 90 degrees (inclusive).
In simple cases, the isocline curves returned might be lines or arcs. But, more commonly, this function will return spline curves that approximate the true isocline curves to within modeling tolerances.
The following example creates isocline curves:
The following picture shows the results of the program:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.IsoparametricCurve(Snap.NX.Face,Snap.Create.DirectionUV,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Creates isoparametric curves in U or V direction on a given face
member.param: The face used to create isoparametric curves
The direction of the curves, u = constant or v = constant
The constant parameter value at which to create the iso-curves
Tolerance value, explained below. Optional. Default = 0.0254

remarks.para: If UV = DirectionUV.U, then the isoparametric curves will have U = constant.

If the face is an offset surface or a foreign surface, the iso-curves are approximations, and the accuracy of the approximation is controlled by the input tolerance. In other cases, the isoparametric curves can be created exactly, so the tolerance is not used.
If the face has not been trimmed, then this function will always return a single curve.
The different Snap.NX.Face types also have IsoCurveU and IsoCurveV methods. These may be more convenient because they return curves of specific known types.

member.example: The following example shows how to create isoparametric curves:
member.exception: Iso-curve of form v=constant requested on a blend face, which is not supported.

member.name: M:Snap.Create.JoinCurves(Snap.NX.ICurve[])
member.summary: Creates a spline curve by joining together a string of given curves
member.param: The curves to be joined (NX.Curve or NX.Edge objects)

remarks.para: The string of curves or edges that you input may not have large gaps (larger than the current DistanceTolerance). If the input curves have sharp corners where they join, a spline will be created, but it will also contain sharp corners, so it may not be acceptable as input to some NX functions.
The order of the given curves in the input array doesnt matter.
To convert a single curve into a spline, you should use the ToSpline method.

member.example: This example shows how to join curves:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.LineTangent(Snap.Position,Snap.NX.ICurve,Snap.Position)
member.summary: Creates a line through a given point, tangent to a curve
member.param: Point through which the line passes
A point near the desired tangency point

remarks.para: The line will start at the given point, and end at the tangent point on the curve.
The help point does not have to lie on the curve, just somewhere near the desired tangency point.
If the base point lies on the curve, then an infinite line is generated. In this case, the help point has no influence.
If the base point and the curve are not in the same plane, then the base point is projected to the plane of the curve, and a tangent line is generated between the projected point and the given curve.

member.example: This example shows how to create a tangent line:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.LineTangent(Snap.NX.ICurve,Snap.Position,Snap.NX.ICurve,Snap.Position)
member.summary: Creates a line tangent to two curves
member.param: A point near the desired tangency point on the first curve
A point near the desired tangency point on the second curve

remarks.para: The line will start and end at the tangency points on the two curves.
The help points do not have to lie on the curves, just somewhere near the desired tangency points.
If the two given curves are not coplanar, then the second curve is projected to the plane of the first curve, and a tangent line is constructed between the first curve and the projected one.

member.example: This example shows how to create a line tangent to two curves:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.LineTangent(Snap.NX.ICurve,System.Double,Snap.Position)
member.summary: Creates a line at a given angle, tangent to a given curve
member.param: A curve or edge lying in a plane parallel to the XY-plane
An angle measured relative to the X-axis
A point near the desired tangency point

remarks.para: The line created has "infinite" length; specifically, its length is limited by the bounding box of the model.

member.exception: The input curve is a line, is non-planar, or does not lie in a plane parallel to the XY-plane
member.example: This example shows how to create a tangent line:

Point on the axis of revolution
Vector along the axis of revolution (magnitude doesn't matter)
Angular extents of the revolved shape, in degrees, measured from the input curves
Offset distances controlling the wall thickness of the shell

member.summary: Creates a ruled feature
member.param: If true, direction of curve0 is reversed (see remarks below)
If true, direction of curve1 is reversed

remarks.para: If reverse0 is False, the v=0 isoparametric curve of the ruled surface passes through the start-point of curve0; if True, it passes through the end-point of this curve. Similar remarks apply to reverse1 and curve1. So, by adjusting the values of reverse0 and reverse1, you can control the twisting of the ruled surface.

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Spline(System.Double[],Snap.Position[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Creates a rational spline curve from knots, poles, and weights
member.param: Knots -- an array of n+k knot values : t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
An array of n 3D positions representing poles
An array of n weight values

remarks.para: To create a spline that passes through a given set of points, you can use the SplineThroughPoints functions.
To create a Bezier curve (which is a spline having only a single segment), you can use the BezierCurve functions.
Another way to create a spline curve is by converting a curve of some other type. You can do this by using the ToSpline function.

member.example: The following example creates a spline:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.Spline(System.Double[],Snap.Position[])
member.summary: Creates a polynomial spline curve from knots and poles

An array of n 3D positions representing poles
member.example: The following example creates a spline:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.SplineThroughPoints(Snap.Position[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Creates a spline curve interpolating (passing through) a given sequence of points
member.param: The n points to be interpolated
The n parameter values at which to interpolate
Knot sequence : n+k values t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]

remarks.para: The spline passes through the i-th data point points[i] at the parameter value t = nodes[i]. In other words, if we denote the spline by S, then we have S(nodes[i]) = points[i] for 0 ≤ i < n.

Choosing "good" values for the nodes and knots is not easy. The Snap.Math.SplineMath class has some tools to help you. But, unless you are a spline expert, it's probably best to create your splines by using other SNAP functions that don't require nodes and knots as input.

member.example: The following example creates a spline:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.SplineThroughPoints(Snap.Position[],System.Int32)
member.summary: Creates a spline curve interpolating (passing through) a given sequence of points
member.param: The n points to be interpolated
The degree of the desired spline

remarks.para: For most purposes, a degree of 3 (a cubic spline) works fine.

member.example: The following example creates a spline:

member.name: M:Snap.Create.SplineThroughPoints(Snap.Position[],Snap.Vector,Snap.Vector)
member.summary: Creates a cubic (degree = 3) spline curve interpolating given points and end tangents
member.param: The n points to be interpolated
The desired tangent vector at the start of the curve (magnitude doesn't matter)
The desired tangent vector at the end of the curve (magnitude doesn't matter)

remarks.para: Only the directions of the input start and end tangents are used by this function, so the magnitudes of these vectors have no effect on the shape of the resulting curve.

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.ClosestPoints(Snap.NX.NXObject,Snap.NX.NXObject)
member.summary: Computes the closest points on two given objects (curves, edges, faces, or bodies)
member.param: The first object (curve, edge, face, or body)
The second object (curve, edge, face, or body)
member.returns: A Compute.DistanceResult object that contains the distance and the closest points

remarks.para: The closest points on the two objects are returned in DistanceResult.Point1 and DistanceResult.Point2. If you only want to know the distance between the objects (and not the closest points), then the Snap.Compute.Distance function may be more convenient.

remarks.para: The closest point of the object is returned in DistanceResult.Point2.
If you only want to know the distance between the objects (and not the closest points), then the Snap.Compute.Distance function may be more convenient.

member.exception: The input object is not a curve, edge, face, or body

member.name: T:Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult
member.summary: Represents the result of an intersection calculation

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult.Position
member.summary: Location of the intersection point (or Nothing if no intersection was found)

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult.CurveParameter
member.summary: The parameter value of the intersection point on the first object (which is either a curve or a ray)

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult.ObjectParameters
member.summary: The parameter value(s) of the intersection point on the second object

remarks.para: The array always has length = 2, but its elements have different meaning, depending on the type of the second object:
Face or body -- ObjectParameters[0,1] = the uv-values at the intersection point.
Curve or edge -- ObjectParameters[0] = the curve parameter value at the intersection point.
Plane or datum plane -- ObjectParameters has no meaningful information

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult.Create(NXOpen.UF.UFCurve.IntersectInfo)
member.summary: Creates a Snap.Compute.IntersectionResult from an NXOpen.UF.UFCurve.IntersectInfo

remarks.para: Just copies information. Leaves the ObjectParameters field set to Nothing (to be filled in later, by the caller)

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.Intersect(Snap.Geom.Surface.Plane,Snap.Geom.Surface.Plane,Snap.Geom.Surface.Plane)
member.summary: Computes the point of intersection of three planes
member.returns: Location of the intersection point, or Nothing if not found

remarks.para: Mathematically, the intersection of three planes could be either a point, an infinite line, a plane, or nothing (the empty set). This function only handles the case where the intersection is a point. In all other cases, it returns Nothing.

member.example: The following example shows how to intersect three planes:

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.Intersect(Snap.Geom.Surface.Plane,Snap.Geom.Surface.Plane)
member.summary: Computes the intersection of two planes (a ray)
member.returns: The line of intersection, represented as a ray, or Nothing if not found
member.remarks:
Mathematically, the intersection of two planes could be either a line, a plane, or nothing (the empty set). This function only handles the case where the intersection is a line (i.e. the case where the two planes are
not parallel). If the planes are parallel, it returns Nothing.
member.example: The following example shows how to intersect two planes:

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.ClipRay(Snap.Geom.Curve.Ray)
member.summary: Clips a ray to the model bounding box (the 1 KM cube), giving a line

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.MassProperties(Snap.NX.Body[])
member.summary: Calculates the mass properties of a given list of bodies

remarks.para: The input can be a (mixed) array of solid bodies and sheet bodies. Sheet bodies are assumed to represent thin-walled objects, so they will have non-zero mass and moments of inertia.
If the work part's unit is mm, then the return values will use the gram-mm system of units.
If work part's unit is inch, then the return values will use the pound-inch system of units.
As always in SNAP, the return values are relative to the absolute coordinate system.
Before computing mass and moments of inertia, you must assign the correct density to the bodies, using the Snap.NX.Body.Density property.

SNAP provides simpler functions for calculating mass, volume, and surface area specifically. If you only need one or two of these quantities, these simpler functions might be easier for you to use. Links to these functions are provided in the "See Also" section below.

member.example: The following example shows how to calculate mass properties:

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.Mass(Snap.NX.Body[])
member.summary: Computes the total mass of a collection of bodies
member.returns: The total mass of the given array of bodies

remarks.para: The input can be a (mixed) array of solid bodies and sheet bodies. Sheet bodies are assumed to represent thin-walled objects, so they will have non-zero mass.
If the work part's unit is mm, then the return values will be in grams.
If work part's unit is inch, then the return values will be in pounds.
Before computing mass, you must assign the correct density to the bodies, using the Snap.NX.Body.Density property.
If you want to calculate several mass properties (rather than just mass), using the Snap.Compute.MassProperties function will provide better performance.

member.example: The following example shows how to calculate mass:

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.Volume(Snap.NX.Body[])
member.summary: Computes the total volume of a collection of bodies
member.returns: The total volume of the given array of bodies

remarks.para: The input can be a (mixed) array of solid bodies and sheet bodies. However, the volume of a sheet body is always zero, of course.
If the work part's unit is mm, then the return values will be in cubic mm.
If work part's unit is inch, then the return values will be in cubic inches.
If you want to calculate several mass properties (rather than just volume), using the Snap.Compute.MassProperties function will provide better performance.

member.example: The following example shows how to compute the volume of a collection of bodies.

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.MomentOfInertia(Snap.Position,Snap.Vector,Snap.NX.Body[])
member.summary: Calculates the moment of inertia of a collection of bodies around a given axis
member.param: A point on the axis line
A vector along the axis line (length doesn't matter)
member.returns: The moment of inertia around the given axis

remarks.para: The input can be a (mixed) array of solid bodies and sheet bodies. Sheet bodies are assumed to represent thin-walled objects, so they will have non-zero moments of inertia.
If the work part's unit is mm, then the return values will use the gram-mm system of units.
If work part's unit is inch, then the return values will use the pound-inch system of units.
Before computing moments of inertia, you must assign the correct density to the bodies, using the Snap.NX.Body.Density property.
If you want to calculate several mass properties (rather than just moments of inertia), using the Snap.Compute.MassProperties function will provide better performance.

member.summary: The centroid of the collection of bodies

member.remarks: The axes are unit vectors

member.summary: The principal moments of the collection of bodies at the centroid, in order, largest first

member.summary: The radius of gyration of the collection of bodies
member.remarks: This is returned only when the input is an array of solid bodies

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.MassPropertiesResult.Density
member.summary: The density of the overall collection of bodies (total mass divided by total volume or area)

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.MassPropertiesResult.InertiaTensor
member.summary: The inertia tensor at the centroid

remarks.para: The inertia tensor is a symmetric 3×3 matrix whose entries are moments and products of inertia. It can be used to compute the moment of inertia around any axis through the centroid of the collection of bodies, although the "Snap.Compute.MomentOfInertia" function provides an easier way to do this.

If we denote the inertia tensor by M, then we can immediately obtain moments of inertia around certain specific lines through the centroid:
M[0,0] is the moment of inertia around a line parallel to the x-axis
M[1,1] is the moment of inertia around a line parallel to the y-axis
M[2,2] is the moment of inertia around a line parallel to the z-axis

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.MassPropertiesResult.MomentsOfInertia
member.summary: Moments of inertia about X, Y, Z axes (Ixx, Iyy, Izz)

member.name: P:Snap.Compute.MassPropertiesResult.ProductsOfInertia
member.summary: Products of inertia about X, Y, Z axes (Myz, Mzx, Mzy, in that order)

member.name: M:Snap.Compute.MinimumRadius(Snap.NX.Face)
member.summary: Computes the minimum radius of curvature of a face

remarks.para: Gets the minimum radius of curvature on each side of the given face, where one exists, and its position and u-v parameters.

A minimum radius of curvature is deemed not to exist on one side of the surface if it is nowhere concave on that side. So the function can return 0 (in the case of a plane), 1 (in the case of a cylinder, for example) or 2 minima.
The radius of curvature has a positive sign if the surface is concave with respect to its normal and a negative sign if the surface is convex with respect to its normal.

The corners are returned in the following order:

Corners[2] is the point ( MinX, MaxY, MinZ)

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Surface
member.summary: Represents a non-persistent infinite surface -- not stored in NX

remarks.para: The most common use for Geom.Surface objects is to return information about the geometry of faces. Specifically, the Geometry property of an NX.Face returns a Geom.Surface object of the appropriate type, which you can then use to obtain geometric information. Examples of this usage are given in the many of the derived classes, such as Geom.Surface.Plane, Geom.Surface.Cone, and Geom.Surface.Bsurface, and others.

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Surface.Bsurface
member.summary: Represents a non-persistent B-surface object -- not stored in NX
member.remarks:
A Snap.Geom.Surface.Bsurface is very similar to a Snap.NX.Bsurface, of course. The big difference is that the latter is an object in an NX part file, whereas the former is a non-persistent object that only exists in memory while your program is running. Geom objects are completely independent of the NX database, and can even be used outside of NX sessions. For this reason, computations on Geom objects are often much faster than similar computations on NX objects.
The representation used here consists of
Poles -- A 2D array of nu x nv 3D poles (control vertices)
KnotsU -- An array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
KnotsV -- An array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , u[nv+kv-1]
Weights -- A 2D array of nu x nv weight values
The degrees of the surface in the u and v directions are determined by the sizes of the given arrays:
DegreeU = knotsU.Length - Poles.GetLength(0) - 1
DegreeV = knotsV.Length - Poles.GetLength(1) - 1
Poles p[0,0], p[0,1], ... ,p[0,nv-1] lie along edge u = 0 (0 < v < 1)
Poles p[0,0], p[1,0], ... ,p[nu-1,0] lie along edge v = 0 (0 < u < 1)
So, in particular
p[0,0] = S(0,0)
p[0,nv-1] = S(0,1)
p[nu-1,0] = S(1,0)
p[nu-1,nv-1] = S(1,1)
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the Geom.Surface.Bsurface class:

member.remarks: The weights must be positive. This is not checked.

member.name: M:Snap.Geom.Surface.Bsurface.#ctor(Snap.Position[0:,0:],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Constructs a polynomial Geom.Bsurface from poles and knot sequences
member.param: A 2D array of nu x nv 3D positions representing poles
Knots for u-direction -- an array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
Knots for v-direction -- an array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , v[nv+kv-1]

remarks.para: The degrees of the surface in the u and v directions are determined by the sizes of the given arrays: DegreeU = knotsU.Length - Poles.GetLength(0) - 1 DegreeV = knotsV.Length - Poles.GetLength(1) - 1
Poles p[0,0], p[0,1], ... ,p[0,mv] lie along edge u = 0 (0 < v < 1) Poles p[0,0], p[1,0], ... ,p[mu,0] lie along edge v = 0 (0 < u < 1)

member.name: M:Snap.Geom.Surface.Bsurface.#ctor(Snap.Position[0:,0:],System.Double[0:,0:],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Constructs a rational Geom.Bsurface from poles, weights, and knot sequences
member.param: A 2D array of nu x nv 3D vectors representing poles
A 2D array of nu x nv values representing weights
Knots for u-direction -- an array of nu+ku knot values : u[0], ... , u[nu+ku-1]
Knots for v-direction -- an array of nv+kv knot values : v[0], ... , v[nv+kv-1]

remarks.para:
The order ku in the u-direction can be inferred from the sizes of the given arrays: nu = number of poles in u-direction = Poles.GetLength(0) npku = nu + ku = number of u-knots = knotsU.Length Then ku = npku - ku. Also, as usual, degree is given by mu = ku - 1. Similarly for the v-direction.
Poles p[0,0], p[0,1], ... ,p[0,mv] lie along edge u = 0 (0 < v < 1) Poles p[0,0], p[1,0], ... ,p[mu,0] lie along edge v = 0 (0 < u < 1)

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Curve
member.summary: Represents a non-persistent curve -- not stored in NX

remarks.para: The most common use for Geom.Curve objects is to return information about the geometry of edges. Specifically, the Geometry property of an NX.Edge returns a Geom.Curve object of the appropriate type, which you can then use to obtain geometric information. Examples of this usage are given in the Geom.Curve.Line, Geom.Curve.Arc, and Geom.Curve.Ellipse classes.

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Curve.Ray
member.summary: Represents a non-persistent infinite line -- not stored in NX
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of a Geom.Curve.Ray object:

member.name: P:Snap.Geom.Curve.Ray.Axis
member.summary: A vector along the ray (a unit vector)

remarks.para: When you set this property, the vector you use does not need to be a unit vector; the input vector will be unitized internally. On the other hand, when you get the value of this property, you will always receive a unit vector. This means that the vector you get may not be the same one you used when setting.

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Curve.Ellipse
member.summary: Represents a non-persistent ellipse -- not stored in NX
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of a Geom.Curve.Ellipse object

member.name: P:Snap.Geom.Curve.Ellipse.RadiusX
member.summary: The half-width of the ellipse in its X-direction

remarks.para: This is the "a" parameter in the standard ellipse equation (x^2)/(a^2) + (y^2)/(b^2) = 1.
It is sometimes known as the "major" radius, but this name is somewhat misleading since it is not necessarily true that RadiusX > RadiusY.

member.name: P:Snap.Geom.Curve.Ellipse.RadiusY
member.summary: The half-width of the ellipse in its Y-direction

remarks.para: This is the "b" parameter in the standard ellipse equation (x^2)/(a^2) + (y^2)/(b^2) = 1.
It is sometimes known as the "minor" radius, but this name is somewhat misleading since it is not necessarily true that RadiusY < RadiusX.

member.name: M:Snap.Geom.Curve.Spline.Position(System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates a point on the curve at a given parameter value
member.param: The index of the span on which the given parameter value lies
member.returns: The point corresponding to the given parameter value

remarks.para: The span index is the number r such that t[r] ≤ t < t[r+1]. Legal values are Degree ≤ r ≤ Knots.Length - 1.

If you don't know the span index, you can use the other Position function, which does not require it as input. But, if you're going to do multiple evaluations on a known span, this function is faster.

member.name: M:Snap.Geom.Curve.Spline.Position(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates a point on the curve at a given parameter value
member.returns: The point corresponding to the given parameter value

remarks.para: You can get exactly the same results by using the Snap.NX.Curve.Position function. However, this function is typically much faster.

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains classes representing temporary abstract geometric objects that are not part of the NX model.

remarks.para: Geom objects are completely independent of the NX database, and can even be used outside of NX sessions. For this reason, computations on Geom objects are often much faster than similar computations on NX objects.

member.name: T:Snap.Geom.Transform

member.name: M:Snap.Geom.Transform.CreateRotation(Snap.Orientation)
member.summary: Creates a transform that performs rotation defined by an orientation

remarks.para: The transform can be applied to Positions, Vectors, and NX objects by calling the appropriate Move or Copy functions.

The transform returned is a rotation around a line through the origin that would move the ACS axes so as to align them with the axes of the given orientation. In NX terms, this is a "reposition" transformation.

member.name: T:Snap.Orientation
member.summary: Represents an orientation in 3D space (interchangeable with NXOpen.Matrix3x3)

remarks.para: An orientation can be regarded either as a 3 × 3 orthogonal matrix, or as a set of three orthogonal unit vectors.
An orientation is a temporary non-persistent object that does not get stored in any NX part file. If you want to create a permanent object, you should use a Snap.NX.Matrix object, instead.

member.example: The following example shows how to use the orientation class:

member.name: P:Snap.Orientation.Identity
member.summary: Returns the identity Orientation

member.name: P:Snap.Orientation.AxisX
member.summary: The X-axis of the orientation (unit vector)

member.name: P:Snap.Orientation.AxisY
member.summary: The Y-axis of the orientation (unit vector)

member.name: P:Snap.Orientation.AxisZ
member.summary: The Z-axis of the orientation (unit vector)

member.name: P:Snap.Orientation.Array
member.summary: The array representation of the orientation

remarks.para: The array elements are organized as follows:
array[0,0] = axisX.X ; array[0,1] = axisX.Y ; array[0,2] = axisX.Z
array[1,0] = axisY.X ; array[1,1] = axisY.Y ; array[1,2] = axisY.Z
array[2,0] = axisZ.X ; array[2,1] = axisZ.Y ; array[2,2] = axisZ.Z

member.name: M:Snap.Orientation.#ctor
member.summary: Constructor for the identity Orientation

member.name: M:Snap.Orientation.#ctor(Snap.Vector,Snap.Vector,Snap.Vector)
member.summary: Constructor, given three orthogonal unit vectors
member.param: Unit vector to be used as X-axis
Unit vector to be used as Y-axis
Unit vector to be used as Z-axis
member.remarks:
The three vectors should be orthonormal (unit length
and mutually perpendicular). This function does not check this.

member.name: M:Snap.Orientation.#ctor(Snap.Vector,Snap.Vector)
member.summary: Constructor, given X and Y axes

remarks.para: The input X-axis vector does not have to be a unit vector.
The input Y-axis vector does not have be a unit vector, and it does not have to be perpendicular to the X-axis. It just has to be in the correct plane and on the correct "side" of the X-axis.

member.name: M:Snap.Orientation.#ctor(Snap.Vector)
member.summary: Constructor, given a Z-axis vector
member.param: Vector to be used as the Z-axis of the orientation (length doesn't matter)
member.returns: Orientation having the given vector as its Z-axis

remarks.para: The X and Y axes are constructed arbitrarily, so use this constructor only when you don't care about these other axes.

member.name: T:Snap.Position
member.summary: Represents a position in 3D space (interchangeable with NXOpen.Point3d)

remarks.para: Provides functions for creating positions, and for operations like sum, difference, and scalar multiplication using the normal arithmetic (in-fix) notation.
The concept is similar to the NX Point3d object, but the implementation here provides more capability.

member.example: The following example shows how to use the Position class:

member.name: F:Snap.Position.X
member.summary: The x-coordinate of the position

member.name: F:Snap.Position.Y
member.summary: The y-coordinate of the position

member.name: F:Snap.Position.Z
member.summary: The z-coordinate of the position

member.name: F:Snap.Position.Origin
member.summary: A position corresponding to the origin -- (0,0,0)

member.name: P:Snap.Position.Array
member.summary: Array of the coordinates of the position

member.name: P:Snap.Position.PolarTheta
member.summary: The polar angle "theta" -- angle of rotation in the XY-plane

remarks.para: The function returns Math.Atan2(y, x) * 180/Math.PI. So, the returned angle is always between -180 and 180. See the .NET documentation for Math.Atan2 for further details.
The Snap.Vector class has a similar property, and its description includes an explanatory picture.

member.name: P:Snap.Position.PolarPhi
member.summary: The polar angle "phi" -- the angle between the position and the XY-plane

remarks.para: The function returns Snap.Math.Atan2( Sqrt(x*x + y*y), z). So, the returned angle is always between -180 and 180. See the .NET documentation for Math.Atan2 for further details.
The Snap.Vector class has a similar property, and its description includes an explanatory picture.

member.name: M:Snap.Position.ToString
member.summary: Produces a string representation of a Position object
member.returns: String in the form (X, Y, Z)

remarks.para: The string representation is in either fixed-point or scientific (exponential) form, whichever is more compact, and with the decimal point represented by a period symbol.

member.name: M:Snap.Position.ToString(System.String)
member.summary: Produces a string representation of a Position object using a given format
member.returns: String in the form (X, Y, Z)

remarks.para: The X, Y, Z coordinates are converted to strings using the given format and the standard .NET Double.ToString function. This means that the string depends on your Windows "culture" settings. In particular, the decimal point might be represented by either a period or a comma, depending on your settings.

member.example: The following example shows how to represent a Position object with given formats:

member.remarks:

so it is sometimes useful for performance reasons.

member.name: T:Snap.Vector
member.summary: Represents a vector in 3D space (interchangeable with NXOpen.Vector3d)

remarks.para: Provides functions for creating vectors, and for doing operations like sum, difference, and scalar multiplication using the normal arithmetic (in-fix) notation. Also provides dot and cross products, unitizing, and measuring angles. The concept is similar to the NX/Open Vector3d object, but the implementation here provides far more capability.

remarks.para: The X, Y, Z components are converted to strings using the given format and the standard .NET Double.ToString function. member.name: P:Snap.Vector.PolarPhi
member.summary: The polar angle "phi" -- angle between the vector and the XY-plane, in degrees

remarks.para: The function returns Snap.Math.Atan2(Sqrt(x*x + y*y), z). So, the returned angle is always between -180 and 180. See the .NET documentation for Math.Atan2 for further details.

member.name: T:Snap.ChebyshevPoles
member.summary: Poles of constrained Chebyshev polynomials whose leading coefficients are 1.

remarks.para: These poles are useful for degree reduction. These are actually the leading coefficients of the Chebyshev polynomials defined on [-1,1]. To get the leading coefficients of polynomials on [0,1], divide by (-2)^m.

member.summary: Performs simple linear algebra computations

member.summary: Represents the results of an eigenvalue/eigenvector calculation

member.summary: An eigenvalue

member.summary: The corresponding eigenvector

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.EigenSystem(System.Double[0:,0:])
member.summary: Computes the eigensystem (eigenvalues and eigenvectors) of a matrix
member.returns: Array of results (pairs of eigenvalue and eigenvector)

remarks.para: The matrix must be square (obviously). This is not checked.
Currently, this function works only if the input matrix is 3 × 3 and symmetric. This makes it useful for moment of inertia calculations, but not much else.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.EigenSolver3.ComputeRoots(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Double[])
member.summary: Compute the eigenvalues of a given 3x3 symmetric matrix

remarks.para: The eigenvalues are the roots of the characteristic equation. Since the matrix is 3 × 3, this equation is cubic. Since the matrix is symmetric, the eigenvalues are guaranteed to all be real. Since the matrix is positive semi-definite, the eigenvalues are guaranteed to be positive.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.EigenSolver3.IsPositiveRank(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Double@,Snap.Vector@)
member.summary: Determine if a matrix has positive rank
member.param: The matrix entry with maximum magnitude
The row of the matrix in which the maximum-magnitude entry resides
member.returns: True if the matrix has positive rank

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.LUDecomposition(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Int32[],System.Double)
member.summary: Modifies a square matrix to LU decomposition form
member.param: Square matrix (input and output) -- modified upon output
Permutation info, for use by back substitution
Even/odd indicator. Used to calculate determinant.

remarks.para: Given a square matrix a[0..n-1][0..n-1], this routine replaces it by the LU decomposition of a row-wise permutation of itself.
The output index[0..n-1] records the row permutation effected by the partial pivoting.
This function is used in combination with BackSubstitution to solve linear equations or to invert a matrix.

member.exception: The input matrix is singular.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.BackSubstitution(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Int32[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Performs "back substitution" to solve a linear system, given an LU decomposition
member.param: An LU decomposition of matrix a, as produced by LUDecomposition
On input, the right-hand side. On output, the solution vector

remarks.para: This function solves a set of n linear equations a.x = b.
The coefficient matrix a[0..n-1][0..n-1] must be input in LU decomposition form, as output from the functions LUDecomposition.
The permutation vector index[0..n-1] is also obtained from the function LUDecomposition.
The vector b[0..n-1] is used for both input and output. On input, it contains the right-hand side of the set of equations, and on output, it contains the solution vector.
The variables a and index are not modified by this function, so you can re-use them in successive calls with different values of the right-hand side b.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.LinearAlgebra.BackSolve(System.Double[0:,0:],System.Int32[],System.Double[])
member.summary: Performs "back substitution" to solve a linear system, given an LU decomposition
member.param: An LU decomposition of matrix a, as produced by LUDecomposition

remarks.para: This function solves a set of n linear equations a.x = b.
The coefficient matrix a[0..n-1][0..n-1] must be input in LU decomposition form, as output from the functions LUDecomposition.
The permutation vector index[0..n-1] is also obtained from the function LUDecomposition.
The variables a and index are not modified by this function, so you can re-use them in successive calls with different values of the right-hand side b.

member.name: T:Snap.Math.DoubleFunction
member.summary: A real-valued function, for use in root-finding
member.param: Data item to be used in evaluation
member.returns: The function value f(x) at the given argument value
member.remarks: You use a DoubleFunction when finding roots using the FindRealRoot function.

member.name: T:Snap.Math.Roots
member.summary: Tools for finding roots (zeros) of real-valued functions

member.name: M:Snap.Math.Roots.FindRealRoot(Snap.Math.DoubleFunction,System.Object,System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Finds a single real root of a given function f in an interval [x1, x2]
member.param: The function whose root we want to find
Data to be passed to the function f
The desired accuracy of the root
member.returns: A root x with x1 < x < x2

remarks.para: The function must have different signs at the end-points of the given interval. In other words, f(x1) and f(x2) must have different signs. If there are several roots in the interval [x1,x2], this function will find one of them, but we can't say which one.
The returned root is guaranteed to differ from a true root by at most rootError.

When calling this function, you can omit the maxIterations argument, in which case a value of 20 is used. Reasonable values are in the range 20 to 50. More iterations will be needed if the interval [x1, x2] is very wide or the specified rootError is very small. If the algorithm doesn't converge within 100 iterations, then it probably won't converge at all, which might mean that you need to find a different way to express your problem.

member.example: The following example uses the FindRealRoot function to find the parameter value where a curve has a certain given radius of curvature.
member.exception: Function values f(x1) and f(x2) have the same sign
Maximum number of iterations exceeded

member.name: M:Snap.Math.Roots.Negate(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Returns a or -a, depending on whether a and b have same sign
member.param: Value determining whether or not to negate
member.returns: a or -a, depending on whether a and b have same or different sign
member.remarks: Returns a if a and b are either both non-negative or both negative. Returns -a otherwise.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.Roots.FindRealRoots(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Find the real roots of a quadratic equation a*x^2 + b*x + c = 0
member.remarks:
The returned array may have length zero, one, or two.
One root will be returned only if the coefficient a is zero. In other cases, either zero or two roots will be returned. If the equation has two equal roots, then these will be returned as two individual elements of the array.
When two roots are returned, the first one will be less than or equal to the second one.
member.exception: The coefficients a and b are both zero

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.BsplineInterpolation(System.Double[],System.Double[],System.Double[])
member.summary: B-spline interpolation (1D -- real-valued)
member.param: The n values to interpolate, q[0],...,q[n-1]
The n parameter values at which to interpolate, tau[0],...,tau[n-1]
Knot sequence : n-k values t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
member.returns: The n "poles" (ordinate values) p[0],...,p[n-1] of the interpolating b-spline

remarks.para: This function does 1-D (i.e. real-valued) interpolation. To do 3D interpolation, you would have to call it three times -- for x, y, and z. However, it is much more efficient to call the other BsplineInterpolation overload, which receives positions as input.

First derivative at t=0 (wrt a parameter that varies from 0 to 1)
First derivative at t=1 (wrt a parameter that varies from 0 to 1)

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.BasisMatrix(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates a matrix of basis function values
member.param: Knot sequence : n+k values t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
Parameter (n) values at which to evaluate, tau[0],...,tau[n-1]
member.returns: Matrix (n x n) of basis function values, B(i,k)(nodes[j])

remarks.para: There are n basis functions, numbered B(0,k), B(1,k), ... , B(n-1,k).
The i-th basis function B(i,k) is non-zero only for t[i] < t < t[i+k]
In the matrix A : A[j][i] = B(i,k)(tau[j]) (i = 0,1,...,n-1 ; j = 0,1,...,n-1)

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.EvaluateBasisFunction(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Evaluates value of a b-spline basis function
member.param: Knot sequence : n+k values t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
Parameter value at which to evaluate
member.returns: Value of i-th basis function B(i,k)(t)

remarks.para: There are n basis functions, numbered B(0,k), B(1,k), ... , B(n-1,k).
The i-th basis function B(i,k) is non-zero only for t[i] < t < t[i+k]

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.EvaluateBasisFunction(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates a b-spline basis function and/or optional derivatives
member.param: The knot sequence : n+k values t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
Parameter value at which to evaluate
Number of derivatives requested (0 for position alone)

remarks.para: Copied from h0916, which in turn came from deBoor's book.
There are n basis functions, numbered B(0,k), B(1,k), ... , B(n-1,k).
The i-th basis function B(i,k) is non-zero only for t[i] < tau < t[i+k]

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.FindSpan(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double)
member.summary: Finds the knot vector span containing a given value
member.param: The knot sequence : n+k+1 values t[0], ... , t[n+k]
Order of the basis functions (k = m+1 = degree+1)
Parameter value whose span we want to find
member.returns: The span index; a number r such that t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]

remarks.para: The span index r returned by this function is always in the range m ≤ r ≤ n.
If tau < t[m], we return m, so subsequent evaluations of a basis function at tau will actually be using the polynomial that agrees with this basis function on the first span t[m] ≤ t < t[m+1].
If tau > t[n], we return n. So, subsequent evaluations of a basis function at tau will actually be using the polynomial that agrees with this basis function on the last span t[n-1] ≤ t < t[n].

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.EvaluateBasisFunctions(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Evaluates the k b-spline basis functions that are non-zero on a given span
member.param: The knot sequence : n+k+1 values t[0], ... , t[n+k]
Order of the basis functions (k = m+1 = degree+1)
Parameter value at which to evaluate
The span number: t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]
member.returns: Values at tau of the k basis functions that are non-zero on the span t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]

remarks.para: This is based on the function "BasisFuncs" in Tiller's book. Algorithm 2.2, page 70.

There are k basis functions that are non-zero on the span where t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]. In fact these basis functions are B(r-m,k), B(r-m+1,k), ... , B(r,k), where B(i,k) is the basis function of order k that is non-zero on the interval t[i] ≤ tau < t[i+k]
The span number r must lie in the range m ≤ r ≤ n.

member.name: M:Snap.Math.SplineMath.EvaluateBasisFunctions(System.Double[],System.Int32,System.Double,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates the value and derivatives of the k b-spline basis functions that are non-zero on a given span
member.param: The knot sequence : n+k+1 values t[0], ... , t[n+k]
Order of the basis functions (k = m+1 = degree+1)
Parameter value at which to evaluate
The span number r such that t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]
How many derivatives to compute. Set numDerivs = 0 for function values alone
member.returns: Values at tau of the k basis functions that are non-zero there.

remarks.para: This is based on the function "xxx" in Tiller's book. Algorithm 2.2, page 70.

There are k basis functions that are non-zero on the span where t[r] ≤ tau < t[r+1]. In fact these basis functions are B(r-m,k), B(r-m+1,k), ... , B(r,k), where B(i,k) is the basis function of order k that is non-zero on the interval t[i] ≤ tau < t[i+k]
The span number r must lie in the range m ≤ r ≤ n.
derivs[i,j] is the i-th derivative of the j-th basis function
If you don't know the span corresponding to the given tau value, you can get it by calling FindSpan.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Arc.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype arc of this one (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if this arc is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Body.Density
member.summary: The density of the body

remarks.para: A sheet body is assumed to represent a thin-walled object, so its density is mass per unit area.
If the part units are millimeters, the density units are gm/mm^3 for solid bodies, or gm/mm^2 for sheet bodies.
If the part units are inches, the density units are lb/in^3 for solid bodies, or lb/in^2 for sheet bodies.

member.summary: If true, indicates that the body is a solid

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Body.IsSheetBody
member.summary: If true, indicates that the body is a sheet

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Body.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype body of this body (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the body is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Component
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Component object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Assemblies.Component)

remarks.para: SNAP does not yet provide any functions for inserting new components into part files. The only thing you can do at present is read assembly/component information. This is useful for writing reports of various kinds.
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly/component concepts.

member.example: This example shows how to use some of the properties of the NX.Component class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.NXOpenComponent
member.summary: The enclosed NXOpen.Assemblies.Component object

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Box
member.summary: The 3D box that encloses the component

remarks.para: The box is computed by combining the boxes of the member objects of the component. If the component has no boxable members, then Nothing is returned.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Members
member.summary: An array containing all the member objects of this component

remarks.para: The returned array contains all the objects in the component, possibly including some that SNAP knows nothing about.
The members are all "occurrences". These are objects that are merely links to "real" objects that actually reside in subassemblies, rather than in the current part.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Parent
member.summary: The parent component of this component

remarks.para: Components are arranged in a "tree" that represents the hierarchical structure of an assembly. Within this tree, the components one level down from the current one are known as its "children", and the component one level up is known as its "parent".
If the current component has no parent (because it is a root node, then this property will have the value Nothing.
You can determine that a component is a root node by using its IsRoot property.
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to these concepts.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Children
member.summary: The child components of this component

remarks.para: Components are arranged in a "tree" that represents the hierarchical structure of an assembly. Within this tree, the components one level down from the current one are known as its "children", and the component one level up is known as its "parent".
If the current component has no children (because it is a leaf node), the returned array will have length zero.
Note that this property does not return non-geometric components (NGCs) unless the environment variable UGII_ALLOW_NGC_IN_UGOPEN is set to YES.
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to these concepts.

By using the Children property, you can recursively cycle through all the nodes in a tree of components. The example program below shows you how to do this. However, in many situations, you will find that cycling through tree nodes is much easier if you use the Descendants collection or the Leaves collection.

member.example: The following example shows you how to perform some operation on each node of a tree by using a recursive function.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.IsLeaf
member.summary: If True, indicates that this component is a "leaf" node

remarks.para: A "leaf" component is one that's at the lowest level of the component tree, so it has no children.
You can find all the leaf nodes beneath a given component by using the Leaves property.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.IsRoot
member.summary: If True, indicates that this component is a "root" node

remarks.para: A "root" component is one that's at the highest level of the component tree, so it has no parent. A root component is somewhat artificial. It's main purpose is to serve as a convenient starting point for algorithms that want to walk downwards through the component tree.
You can obtain the root component in any given part by using its RootComponent property.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Descendants
member.summary: Returns an enumerable collection containing the component itself, children, grandchildren, and all other descendents.

remarks.para: You can cycle through the Descendants using a "For Each" loop.

member.example: The following example shows how to cycle through descendants:

members.member:
Returns an enumerable collection containing all the "leaf" node components descended from this component.
A "leaf" node is a component that has no children. Leaf nodes are sometimes known as "piece parts", though this terminology is somewhat misleading.
You can cycle through the Leaves collection using a "For Each" loop.
You can determine whether or not a given component is a leaf node by using its IsLeaf property.
The following example shows how to cycle through leaf nodes:
Snap.NX.Component.IsLeaf property.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Prototype
member.summary: The prototype part of this component

remarks.para: A component is created when a part is inserted into an assembly. The part that was inserted becomes the Prototype of the component. The prototype is the source object that supplies the data of the component.
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concept of prototypes.
Note that the return value will be Nothing if you try to get the Prototype property of a component that is not fully loaded, as illustrated in the example code below.

member.example: This example shows use of the Prototype part property, including a check to avoid errors when the prototype part is not fully loaded.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Component.Depth
member.summary: The depth of the component in the component tree hierarchy

remarks.para: The root component has Depth = 0, it's children have Depth = 1, its grandchildren have Depth = 2, and so on.
The Depth property is often useful when writing out indented lists of components.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Cone
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Cone feature (interchangeable with NXOpen.Features.Cone)
member.remarks:
The following picture explains the properties of an NX.Cone object:
There are several restrictions regarding the parameters of an NX.Cone object:
The BaseDiameter and TopDiameter must not be equal
The BaseDiameter and TopDiameter must both be non-negative (zero is OK)
The base arc and the top arc do not need to be coaxial, but they must not be coplanar
The diameters, height, and half-angle must be consistent:
BaseDiameter - TopDiameter = 2 * Height * tan(HalfAngle)
To create an NX.Cone object, use the functions listed below
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Cone class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.AxisPoint
member.summary: The axis point of the cone

remarks.para: This is a point on the axis (center-line) of the cone at the center of the base arc. See the picture for further clarification.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.AxisVector
member.summary: The cone axis vector

remarks.para: This is a vector along the axis of the cone. Its direction is from the center of the base arc to the center of the top arc. See the picture for further clarification.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.BaseDiameter
member.summary: The cone base diameter

remarks.para: This is the diameter of the base arc of the cone. If HalfAngle > 0, then BaseDiameter will be larger than TopDiameter. The BaseDiameter and TopDiameter are not allowed to be equal.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.TopDiameter
member.summary: The cone top diameter

remarks.para: This is the diameter of the top arc of the cone. If HalfAngle > 0, then TopDiameter will be smaller than BaseDiameter. The BaseDiameter and TopDiameter are not allowed to be equal.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.Height
member.summary: The cone height

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.HalfAngle
member.summary: The cone half-angle, in degrees.

remarks.para: This angle will be positive if TopDiameter < BaseDiameter. See the picture for further clarification.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.BaseArc
member.summary: The circle at the base of the cone, with center at the cone's AxisPoint

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Cone.TopArc
member.summary: The circle at the top of the cone (the other end from the BaseArc)
