member.name: T:Snap.NX.Curve
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Curve object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Curve)
member.remarks:
Many of the functions in this class use "parameter" values on curves. There are several different ways to treat parameter values, and this can lead to confusion, sometimes. A common approach is to "unitize" parameter values. This means that the curve parameter has the value u = 0 at the start of the curve, u = 1 at the end of the curve, and intermediate values in the range 0 ≤ u ≤ 1 for intermediate points.
An alternative approach is to use the original parameterization of the curve, without unitizing. With this approach, you have to be aware of the starting and ending parameter values of the curve (MinU and MaxU), since these are not necessarily 0 and 1 respectively.
It is the second (non-unitized) approach that we use in the functions in this class (and throughout Snap).
To illustrate the difference, suppose myArc is a circular arc, and let's consider the point myArc.Position(0.5). This is not the point half-way along the curve, it is the point corresponding to an angle of 0.5 degrees on the arc. If you want the mid-way point, your code should be:
Dim midU as Double = (myArc.MinU + myArc.MaxU)/2 Dim p As Position = myArc.Position(midU)
Similarly, if circ is a complete circle (360 degrees), then the point at 90 degrees is circ.Position(90), not circ.Position(0.25).
The following picture shows some of the properties of an NX.Curve object. The curve shown is the spline created by the example code below, so in this particular case it is true that MinU = 0 and MaxU = 1.

Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the curve is not an occurrence.

member.summary: Calculates points on a curve at given parameter values
member.returns: The points corresponding to the given parameter values

remarks.para: Calling this function is typically around 3× as fast as calling the Curve.Position function in a loop.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Derivative(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative vector on the curve at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The vector returned is usually not a unit vector. In fact, it may even have zero length, in certain unusual cases.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Derivatives(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates curve derivatives (and position) at a given parameter value
member.param: Order of highest derivative returned (zero for position alone)
member.returns: Array of derivative vectors -- [0] is position, [1] is first derivative, etc.

remarks.para: The [0] element of the returned array represents a location on the curve, even though it is contained in a Vector variable. In many cases, you (the caller) should cast this Vector to a Position variable before using it further.
The maximum value allowed for order is 3. Usinga value greater than 3 will result in a run-time error.

member.example: This example shows how to calculate curve derivatives:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Tangent(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the unit tangent vector at a given parameter value

remarks.para: This function successfully calculates a unit tangent vector even in those (rare) cases where the derivative vector of the curve has zero length.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Normal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates unit normal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The normal lies in the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the normal always lies in the plane of the curve.
The normal always points towards the center of curvature of the curve. So, if the curve has an inflexion, the normal will flip from one side to the other, which may be undesirable.
The normal is the cross product of the binormal and the tangent: N = B*T

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Binormal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the unit binormal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The binormal is normal to the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the binormal is normal to the plane of the curve.
The binormal is the cross product of the tangent and the normal: B = Cross(T,N).

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Curvature(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates curvature at a given parameter value

remarks.para: Curvature is the reciprocal of radius of curvature. So, on a straight line, curvature is zero and radius of curvature is infinite. On a circle of radius 5, curvature is 0.2 (and radius of curvature is 5, of course).

member.example: This example shows how to calculate curvature:

member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a point on the curve
member.returns: Parameter value at the point (not unitized)

remarks.para: The Parameter function and the Position function are designed to work together smoothly -- each of these functions is the "reverse" of the other. So, if c is any curve and t is any parameter value, then
Also, if p is any point on the curve c, then

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Parameter(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value defined by an arclength step along a curve
member.param: The curve parameter value at the starting location
The arclength increment along the curve (the length of our step)
member.returns: The curve parameter value at the far end of the step

remarks.para: This function returns the curve parameter value at the far end of a "step" along a curve. The start of the step is defined by a given parameter value, and the size of the step is given by an arclength along the curve. The arclength step may be positive or negative.

member.example: This example shows how to compute parameter increment:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.Parameter(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a fractional arclength value along a curve

remarks.para: The input is a fractional arclength. A value of 0 corresponds to the start of the curve, a value of 1 corresponds to the end-point, and values between 0 and 1 correspond to interior points along the curve.
You can input arclength values outside the range 0 to 1, and this will return parameter values corresponding to points on the extension of the curve.

member.example: This example shows how to compute parameter:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.PositionArray(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates an arrays of positions at equal arclengths on a curve
member.param: The number of positions to be calculated on the curve
member.returns: An array of positions on the curve
member.example: This example shows how to compute positions at equal arclengths on a curve :

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.PositionArray(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculate an array of positions on a curve corresponding to a given chord-height tolerance

remarks.para: A chord is the straight line between adjacent positions on the curve. The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between a chord and the curve itself.

member.returns: An array of positions on the curve
member.example: This example shows how to compute a position array with a given chord-height tolerance:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Curve.PositionArray(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an array of positions on a curve corresponding to given tolerances
member.returns: An array of positions on the curve
member.remarks:
A chord is a straight line between adjacent positions; the blue lines in the picture below are chords.
The three tolerances provide independent values for controlling the positions located along the curve. Their meanings are shown in the following picture
The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between chords and the curve. This is the distance H in the picture above.
The angular tolerance is the maximum allowable sum of the angles between the chord and the tangents to the curve at the ends of the chord. This is the sum A1+A2 in the picture above.
The step tolerance is the maximum allowable length of the chords, which is distance D in the picture.
If any of the input tolerances is zero, it is ignored, so it has no effect. Otherwise, the output positions will satisfy all the given tolerances. Note that the maximum values specified in the tolerances may not be attained; we only guarantee that they will not be exceeded.
member.example: This example shows how to compute an array of positions on a curve:

member.name: T:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity
member.summary: Describes the convexity across an edge (the angle between the faces that meet at the edge)

remarks.para: The picture below shows a cross-section of an extruded shape. The numbered red dots denote edges running into the screen.

These edges have convexities as follows:
Edge E2 is Convex
Edge E3 is Concave
Edges E1,E4,E5,E7,E8,E9 are SmoothConvex
Edge E6 is SmoothInflection

When we say an edge is "smooth", we mean that the two adjacent faces have the same surface normals at points along the edge, so that they join smoothly. Some people would say that the junction is "G1" or "tangent plane continuous".

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.Convex
member.summary: The edge is not smooth, and the material surrounding it spans less than 180 degrees.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.Concave
member.summary: The edge is not smooth, and the material surrounding it spans more than 180 degrees.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.SmoothFlat
member.summary: The edge is smooth, and the adjacent faces have zero curvature along the edge.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.SmoothConvex
member.summary: The edge is smooth, and the adjacent faces are both convex along the edge.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.SmoothConcave
member.summary: The edge is smooth, and the adjacent faces are both concave along the edge.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.SmoothInflection
member.summary: The edge is smooth, and the adjacent faces have opposite convexity along the edge (one is convex and the other is concave).

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.SmoothVariable
member.summary: The edge is smooth, and the adjacent faces have different convexity properties at different points along the edge.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.KnifeConvex
member.summary: The surface normals are anti-parallel and the sum of the curvatures is non-negative.

member.name: F:Snap.NX.EdgeConvexity.KnifeConcave

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Body
member.summary: The body on which the edge lies

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Faces
member.summary: The faces adjacent to the edge

remarks.para: In most cases, there will be two faces adjacent to a given edge. But for "boundary" or "laminar" edges on a sheet body, there will be only one adjacent face.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Shell
member.summary: The shell that the edge belongs to

remarks.para: In NX objects, an edge always belongs to exactly one shell.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Fins
member.summary: The fins of the edge

remarks.para: An edge may have one or two fins. Every edge of a solid body has two fins, but a laminar edge of a sheet body will have only one fin.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.ArcLength
member.summary: The arclength of the edge

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.StartPoint
member.summary: The start point of the edge

remarks.para: This is the point where the parameter u has the value MinU.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.EndPoint
member.summary: The end point of the edge

remarks.para: This is the point where the parameter u has the value MaxU.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Box
member.summary: The 3D box that encloses the edge

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.MinU
member.summary: The lower u-value -- the parameter value at the start-point of the edge

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.MaxU
member.summary: The upper u-value -- the parameter value at the end-point of the edge

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.IsClosed
member.summary: The closed state of edge

remarks.para: An edge is closed if its start-point and end-point are the same.

members.member:
Gets the vertices of the edge An edge may have zero, one, or two vertices. Most edges have either zero or two vertices; edges with one vertex are fairly unusual.
If the edge has zero vertices, then this property will return an array of length zero.
Snap.Topology.Vertex

member.summary: The convexity across this edge

remarks.para: The angular tolerance is used when deciding whether or not the edge is smooth.

member.example: This example shows how to find sharp concave edges:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Plane
member.summary: A plane containing the given edge

remarks.para: This function returns Nothing if the edge is linear (in which case its plane is not well-defined), or if the edge is not planar.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Factor
member.summary: Conversion factor between NX Open and SNAP parameter values. Needed because NX Open uses radians, where SNAP uses degrees

remarks.para: When converting an NX Open parameter to a SNAP parameter, snapValue = nxopenValue * Factor
When converting a SNAP parameter to an NX Open parameter, nxopenValue = snapValue / Factor

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Edge.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype edge of this edge (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the edge is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.#ctor(NXOpen.Edge)
member.summary: Constructor, given an NXOpen.Edge object

remarks.para: The constructor is protected to encourage callers to use CreateEdge, instead, since this ensures proper downcasting. The only callers should be constructors for derived classes.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.CreateEdge(NXOpen.Edge)
member.summary: Creates a Snap.NX.Edge object of the most specific type possible
member.returns: A Snap.NX.Edge object that has the most specific type possible

remarks.para: The returned edge's static type is still Snap.NX.Edge, but, where possible, the NX.Edge variable now contains an edge object whose run-time type is more specific, so that it can be successfully cast to that more specific type by the caller. This is used in Selection, for example.
This function should be used instead of the NX.Edge constructors, to guarantee that properly downcast objects are created whenever possible.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.op_Implicit(NXOpen.Edge)~Snap.NX.Edge
member.summary: Implicit conversion of NXOpen.Edge to NX.Edge
member.returns: A new NX.Edge object enclosing the given NXOpen.Edge

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.op_Implicit(Snap.NX.Edge)~NXOpen.Edge
member.summary: Implicit conversion of NX.Edge to NXOpen.Edge
member.returns: The NXOpen.Edge object enclosed by the given NX.Edge

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Position(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates a point on the edge at a given parameter value
member.returns: Point corresponding to the given parameter value

remarks.para: If you want to calculate several points on an edge, the PositionArray functions might be more useful.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Derivative(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the first derivative vector on the edge at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The vector returned is usually not a unit vector. In fact, it may even have zero length.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Derivatives(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates edge derivatives (and position) at a given parameter value
member.param: Order of highest derivative returned (zero for position alone)
member.returns: Array of derivative vectors -- [0] is position, [1] is first derivative, etc.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Tangent(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the unit tangent vector at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The function calculates a unit tangent vector even in those (rare) cases where the derivative vector of the curve has zero length.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Normal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates unit normal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The normal lies in the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the normal always lies in the plane of the curve.
The normal always points towards the center of curvature of the curve. So, if the curve has an inflexion, the normal will flip from one side to the other, which may be undesirable.
The normal is the cross product of the binormal and the tangent: N = B*T

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Binormal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the unit binormal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The binormal is normal to the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the binormal is normal to the plane of the curve.
The binormal is the cross product of the tangent and the normal: B = Cross(T,N).

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Curvature(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates curvature at a given parameter value

remarks.para: Curvature is the reciprocal of radius of curvature. So, on a straight line, curvature is zero and radius of curvature is infinite. On a circle of radius 5, curvature is 0.2 (and radius of curvature is 5, of course).

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Parameter(Snap.Position)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a point on the edge

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Parameter(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value defined by an arclength step along an edge
member.param: The curve parameter value at the starting location
The arclength increment along the edge (the length of our step)
member.returns: The curve parameter value at the far end of the step

remarks.para: This function returns the curve parameter value at the far end of a "step" along an edge. The start of the step is defined by a given parameter value, and the size of the step is given by an arclength along the edge. The arclength step may be positive or negative.

member.example: This example shows how to compute parameter increment:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Parameter(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a fractional arclength value along an edge

remarks.para: The input is a fractional arclength. A value of 0 corresponds to the start of the edge, a value of 1 corresponds to the end-point, and values between 0 and 1 correspond to interior points along the edge.
You can input arclength values outside the range 0 to 1, and this will return parameter values corresponding to points on the extension of the edge.

member.example: This example shows how to compute parameter:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.ToSpline
member.summary: Creates a spline that replicates the edge

remarks.para: If the edge is a line, arc, ellipse, or spline, the conversion is exact. But, in this case, it will probably be more convenient to use the ToLine, ToArc, or ToEllipse functions.
If the edge is of type intersection curve, then the spline is an approximation, with accuracy controlled by Snap.Globals.DistanceTolerance and Snap.Globals.AngleTolerance.
If you want to convert a string of curves or edges into a spline, please use the Snap.Create.JoinCurves function, instead.

member.example: This example shows how to create splines from edges:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.ToCurve
member.summary: Creates a curve that replicates the edge

remarks.para: If the edge is a line, arc, ellipse, or spline, the conversion is exact, and a curve of the correct type is returned.
If the edge is of type intersection curve, then the returned curve is a spline approximation, with accuracy controlled by Snap.Globals.DistanceTolerance and Snap.Globals.AngleTolerance.
In many situations, there is no need to create a curve replicating the edge. You can just use the edge itself directly, instead.

member.example: This example shows how to create curves from edges:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.PositionArray(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates an arrays of positions at equal arclengths on an edge
member.param: The number of positions to be calculated on the edge
member.returns: An array of positions on the edge
member.example: This example shows how to compute positions at equal arclengths on an edge :

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.PositionArray(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an array of positions on an edge corresponding to a given chord-height tolerance

remarks.para: A chord is the straight line between adjacent positions on the edge. The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between a chord and the edge itself.

member.returns: An array of positions on the edge
member.example: This example shows how to compute a position array with a given chord-height tolerance:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.PositionArray(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an array of positions on an edge corresponding to given tolerances
member.returns: An array of positions on the edge
member.remarks:
A chord is a straight line between adjacent positions. The tolerances provide independent values for controlling the positions located along the edge.
The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between chords and the edge. This is the distance D in the picture below.
The angular tolerance is the maximum allowable sum of the angles between the chord and the tangents to the edge at the ends of the chord. This is the sum A1+A2 in the picture below.
The chord-length tolerance is the maximum allowable length of the chords, which is distance D in the picture.
The following picture shows the meanings of the three tolerances:
If any of the input tolerances is zero, it is ignored, so it has no effect. Otherwise, the output positions will satisfy all the given tolerances. Note that the maximum values specified in the tolerances may not be attained; we only guarantee that they will not be exceeded.
member.example: This example shows how to compute an array of positions on an edge:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Edge.Wrap(NXOpen.Tag)
member.summary: Convert an NXOpen.Edge tag to a Snap.NX.Edge
member.param: The tag of an NXOpen.Edge object to be converted
member.returns: The Snap.NX.Edge object formed by wrapping the NXOpen.Edge having the given tag

remarks.para: In many cases, you can just use an NXOpen object directly in SNAP functions, without wrapping. The main reason for wrapping is to allow use of the properties of the resulting SNAP object.
For more information about wrapping NXOpen objects, please see the section entitled "Mixing SNAP and NX Open" in the SNAP Getting Started Guide; it's the last section in chapter 16.

member.exception: The input tag is NXOpen.Tag.Null, or it doesn't belong to an NXOpen.Edge object

member.summary: Subtypes of NX Ellipse

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Ellipse.RadiusX
member.summary: The half-width of the ellipse in its X-direction

remarks.para: This is the "a" parameter in the standard ellipse equation (x^2)/(a^2) + (y^2)/(b^2) = 1.
It is sometimes known as the "major" radius, but this name is somewhat misleading since it is not necessarily true that RadiusX > RadiusY.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Ellipse.RadiusY
member.summary: The half-width of the ellipse in its Y-direction

remarks.para: This is the "b" parameter in the standard ellipse equation (x^2)/(a^2) + (y^2)/(b^2) = 1.
It is sometimes known as the "minor" radius, but this name is somewhat misleading since it is not necessarily true that RadiusY < RadiusX.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Ellipse.AxisZ

remarks.para: The AxisZ is the cross product AxisX x AxisY.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Expression
member.summary: Represents an expression object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Expression)
member.remarks:
An Expression consists of an "equation" that has three parts:
The "Name" -- the portion before the equals sign (i.e. the left-hand side)
The "RightHandSide" -- the portion after the equals sign but before the comment
The "Comment" -- the portion following the characters "//", up until the end of the equation
So, for example, if the entire equation is
area = pi*r*r // Calculate the area
then the three parts are:
Name: "area"
RightHandSide: "pi*r*r"
Comment: "Calculate the area"
To create an NX.Expression object, use the Snap.Create.Expression functions.
To find all the expressions in a part, use its Expressions collection.
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Expression class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.Comment
member.summary: The comment of the expression (the portion after "//")

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.Descriptor
member.summary: The descriptor for the expression, or Nothing if there is no descriptor

remarks.para: Only an expression that serves as a feature parameter will have a descriptor. The descriptor indicates which feature parameter the expression controls. For example, a cylinder typically has an expression controlling its diameter, which might be listed in the Expression dialog as p26 (Cylinder(7) Diameter). Here, "Diameter" is the Descriptor.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.Equation
member.summary: The entire expression, including name, right-hand-side, and comment

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.IsGeometricExpression
member.summary: If True, indicates that the expression is a geometric expression

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.IsMeasurementExpression
member.summary: If True, indicates that the expression is owned by a measurement

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.IsUserLocked
member.summary: If True, indicates that the expression is user locked

remarks.para: If this property is False, then the expression can be over-ridden from another part. This is the default state for newly created expressions. If this property is True, you are not allowed to over-ride it. Note that if an expression is currently over-ridden, you cannot set its lock property. In this instance, an exception will be thrown.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Expression.OwningFeature
member.summary: The feature that created the expression

remarks.para: This is the feature whose creation caused the creation of the expression.

member.returns: Array of features, or empty array

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Face.Sense
member.summary: The sense of the outward face normal

remarks.para: This property helps you determine on which side of a face material lies.
To compute an outward normal, you first get the "natural" normal by calling the Face.Normal function, and then you multiply this by Face.Sense.

On a cylindrical face, the natural normal points away from the centerline. So, if a cylindrical face has Face.Sense = Sense.Positive, this means that the outward normal also points away from the centerline, so the face must be part of a boss. Similarly, if a cylindrical face has Face.Sense = Sense.Negative, it must be part of a hole.

member.example:
This example shows how to use Face.Sense to construct an outward normal:

remarks.para: In a solid body, the face normal points away from the volume bounded by this shell. In a sheet body, the shell may not bound a volume, of course.

remarks.para: Planes and other non-periodic surfaces have a single outer loop and possibly some hole loops (type Inner). If the surface is periodic in one or two directions, there may not be any clear outer loop. In this case, this property will return Nothing.

member.summary: Returns the prototype face of this face (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the face is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

remarks.para: The Position function and the Parameters function are designed to work together smoothly -- each of these functions is the "reverse" of the other. So, if f is any face and (u,v) is any pair of parameter values, then

member.example: This example shows how to calculate positions and normals on a face:

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Face.Normal(System.Double[])
member.summary: Evaluates the face normal at given (u,v) parameter values
member.param: The (u,v) parameter values -- not normalized to the range [0,1]
member.returns: Face normal at the given (u,v) parameter values (a unit vector)

remarks.para: This function returns the "natural" normal vector, which is parallel to the cross product of the partial derivatives. Typically, Normal(uv) is a unit vector parallel to Cross(DerivDu(uv), DerivDv(uv). However, sometimes one of the partial derivatives is zero. In this case the cross product will also be zero, and will provide no useful information. This function will return a correct surface normal vector even in these unpleasant cases.

The natural face normal directions for some common surface types are as follows:
Cylinder: Away from its centerline
Cone: Away from its centerline
Sphere: Away from its center

It is often useful to compute an "outward" normal on the surface of a solid object (i.e. a normal vector that points away from material, towards empty space). To do this, you compute a natural normal vector using this function, and then adjust its sense using the Face.Sense property.

member.exception: The (u,v) parameter array has the wrong length. You must input two separate values, or an array of length 2.
member.example: This example shows how to get the normal with given U and V parameters:

member.returns: Principal curvatures at the given (u,v) parameter values
member.exception: The (u,v) parameter array has the wrong length. You must input two separate values, or an array of length 2.

remarks.para: Curvature is the reciprocal of radius of curvature. So, on a straight line, curvature is zero and radius of curvature is infinite. On a circle of radius 5, curvature is 0.2 (and radius of curvature is 5, of course).

The principal curvatures at a point on a face are the curvatures of two particular planar sections through that point. For more information, please read about the mathematics of "differential geometry".

The two principal curvatures are returned in ascending order -- the first is smaller (i.e. closer to minus infinity). A principal curvature value will be positive if the corresponding planar section of the surface is concave when viewed from the outside, and negative if the cross-section is convex. A curvature of zero indicates a cross-sectional shape that is a straight line.

For example, on the cylindrical surface of a 20mm diameter hole, the principal curvatures are (0, 0.1). The surface has radius 10, so its larger curvature is 1/10 = 0.1. Similarly, on the cylindrical surface of a 10mm diameter boss, the principal curvatures are (-0.2, 0).

member.example:
This example shows curvature calculations on simple faces:
This example shows curvature calculations on a free-form surface:

member.summary: Finds surface (u,v) parameters at (or nearest to) a given point
member.param: The given point (which should be on or near to the surface)
member.returns: Surface (u,v) parameters at (or near to) the given point

remarks.para: The Parameters function and the Position function are designed to work together smoothly -- each of these functions is the "reverse" of the other. So, if f is any face and (u,v) is any pair of parameter values, then
Also, if p is any point on the face f, then
Note that this function finds parameter values on the underlying surface of the face. So, the values returned may correspond to a surface point that is actually outside the face.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Face.Cylinder
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Face.Cylinder object

remarks.para:
On a cylindrical face, the u and v parameters have the following meanings:
u measures angle around the cylindrical axis, in degrees
v measures straight-line distance along the cylinder, starting from the AxisPoint
The face normal vector is parallel to the cross product of the partial derivatives, and therefore points away from the cylinder axis.

remarks.para:
On a revolved face, the u and v parameters have the following meanings:
u is the parameter of the generator curve
v measures angle around the axis, in degrees, starting from the generator curve
So, the isoparametric curve v = 0 coincides with the generator curve.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Face.SurfaceEvaluate(Snap.NX.Face,System.Int32,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Main surface evaluator function
member.param: The NX.Face on which to evaluate
Mode indicating what returns are needed
member.returns: Various points and derivatives (Position, DerivDu, DerivDv, UnitNormal)
member.remarks:
The "mode" input indicates which derivatives should be calculated:
mode = UF_MODL_EVAL : position only mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_DERIV1 : position and first partials dS/du and dS/dv mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_DERIV2 : position, dS/du, dS/dv, d2S/dudv, d2S/du2, d2S/dv2 mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_DERIV3 : position, first, second, and third partials mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_UNIT_NORMAL : position, first partials, and unitized normal. mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_NORMAL : position, first partials and the non-unitized normal. mode = UF_MODL_EVAL_ALL : position, normals and all the partials up to the third order.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Feature.NXOpenDisplayableObject
member.summary: The associated NXOpen.DisplayableObject of this NX.Feature

remarks.para: This property is identical to NXOpenDisplayableObjects[0]. It serves as a shortcut in the common case where a feature has only a single corresponding displayable object.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Feature.NXOpenDisplayableObjects
member.summary: The associated NXOpen.DisplayableObjects array of this NX.Feature

remarks.para: Here, in the case of a feature, we are over-riding the implementation in NXObject. If the feature consists of a single body, this allows us to confuse the feature with its body. This is useful because it means we can change the color of the feature, blank it, change its layer, and so on. A similar technique is used with Datum Planes and Datum Axes.
See chapter 10 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for further discussion of feature display concepts.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Feature.Body
member.summary: The associated body (an NX.Body object)

remarks.para: If there is more than one body associated with the feature, please use property Feature.Bodies, instead.
If there is no body associated with the feature, the value will be Nothing.

member.exception: There is more than one body associated with this feature.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Feature.Bodies

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Feature.CreateFeature(NXOpen.Features.Feature)
member.summary: Creates a Snap.NX.Feature object of the most specific type possible
member.returns: A Snap.NX.Feature object that has the most specific type possible

remarks.para: The returned feature's static type is still Snap.NX.Feature, but, where possible, the NX.Feature variable now contains a feature object whose run-time type is more specific, so that it can be successfully cast to that more specific type by the caller. This is used in Selection, for example.
This function should be used instead of the NX.Feature constructors, to guarantee that properly downcast objects are created whenever possible.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Feature.op_Implicit(Snap.NX.Feature)~Snap.NX.Body
member.summary: Implicit conversion of NX.Feature to NX.Body

remarks.para: This conversion is provided as a convenience, to avoid the need for explicitly accessing the body (or bodies) of the feature. This makes it possible to use features as input to booleans, change their color, and so on. It should raise an error if the feature has more than one body, but currently does not.

remarks.para: The vector returned is usually not a unit vector. In fact, it may even have zero length, occasionally.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Derivatives(System.Double,System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates icurve derivatives (and position) at a given parameter value
member.param: Order of highest derivative returned (zero for position alone)
member.returns: Array of derivative vectors -- [0] is position, [1] is first derivative, etc.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Tangent(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates unit tangent vector at a given parameter value

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Normal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates unit normal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The normal lies in the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the normal always lies in the plane of the curve.
The normal always points towards the center of curvature of the curve. So, if the curve has an inflexion, the normal will flip from one side to the other, which may be undesirable.
The normal is the cross product of the binormal and the tangent: N = B*T

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Binormal(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the unit binormal at a given parameter value

remarks.para: The binormal is normal to the "osculating plane" of the curve at the given parameter value (the plane that most closely matches the curve). So, if the curve is planar, the binormal is normal to the plane of the curve.
The binormal is the cross product of the tangent and the normal: B = T*N

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Curvature(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates curvature at a given parameter value

remarks.para: Curvature is the reciprocal of radius of curvature. So, on a straight line, curvature is zero and radius of curvature is infinite. On a circle of radius 5, curvature is 0.2 (and radius of curvature is 5, of course).

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Parameter(Snap.Position)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a point on the icurve

remarks.para: As usual in SNAP, the parameter value is not normalized to the range [0,1].

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Parameter(System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value defined by an arclength step along an icurve
member.param: The curve parameter value at the starting location
The arclength increment along the icurve (the length of our step)
member.returns: The curve parameter value at the far end of the step

remarks.para: This function returns the curve parameter value at the far end of a "step" along an icurve. The start of the step is defined by a given parameter value, and the size of the step is given by an arclength along the icurve. The arclength step may be positive or negative.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.Parameter(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates the parameter value at a fractional arclength value along an icurve

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.PositionArray(System.Int32)
member.summary: Calculates an arrays of positions at equal arclengths on a curve or edge
member.param: The number of positions to be calculated on the curve
member.returns: An array of positions on the curve

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.PositionArray(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an array of positions on a curve corresponding to given tolerances
member.returns: An array of positions on the curve
member.remarks:
A chord is a straight line between adjacent positions. The tolerances provide independent values for controlling the positions located along the curve.
The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between chords and the curve. This is the distance D in the picture below.
The angular tolerance is the maximum allowable sum of the angles between the chord and the tangents to the curve at the ends of the chord. This is the sum A1+A2 in the picture below.
The chord-length tolerance is the maximum allowable length of the chords, which is distance D in the picture.
The following picture shows the meanings of the three tolerances:
If any of the input tolerances is zero, it is ignored, so it has no effect. Otherwise, the output positions will satisfy all the given tolerances. Note that the maximum values specified in the tolerances may not be attained; we only guarantee that they will not be exceeded.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.ICurve.PositionArray(System.Double)
member.summary: Calculates an array of positions on a curve corresponding to a given chord-height tolerance

remarks.para: A chord is the straight line between adjacent positions on the curve. The chord-height tolerance is the maximum allowable distance between a chord and the curve itself.

member.returns: An array of positions on the curve

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Note
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Note (interchangeable with NXOpen.Annotations.PmiNote)

remarks.para: To create an NX.Note object, use the Snap.Create.Note functions.

member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Note class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.NXOpenNote
member.summary: The enclosed NXOpen.Annotations.BaseNote object

remarks.para: In a sense, there are two kinds of Snap.NX.Note objects: those that enclose an NXOpen.Annotations.PmiNote object, and those that enclose an NXOpen.Annotations.Note object. The Snap.NX.Note objects created by SNAP functions are always of the first kind. But, when cycling through the NX.Part.Notes array, you may encounter notes of the second kind. In many situations, this doesn't matter, since the properties of the two kinds of enclosed objects are essentially identical.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.NoteBuilder
member.summary: The NXOpen.Annotations.PmiNoteBuilder object.

remarks.para: By using this builder, you can set the properties of the Snap.NX.Note object. After you have finished using the builder, you should call its Destroy() function to free memory.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.Origin
member.summary: The position of the origin of the note

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.Text
member.summary: The text of the note -- an array of lines of text

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.FontIndex
member.summary: The index of the note's font within the part file's font table

remarks.para: It is this index that actually determines the font used to display the note, not the font name. Therefore, if the entries in the font table are re-organized, the note may use a different font, so the appearance of the text will change.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.FontName
member.summary: The name of the primary font used within the note

remarks.para: When setting this property, we first try to find a system (TrueType) font with the given name. If this fails, we look for a traditional NX font, instead. If you want more control over the search process, please use the SetFont function, instead.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.StrokeWidth
member.summary: The width (thickness) of the strokes used to draw the font

remarks.para: The stroke thickness property is only relevant for traditional NX fonts. Truetype fonts are not drawn with strokes, so this property doesnt make sense.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.FontSize
member.summary: The font size (in points)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.Color
member.summary: The color of the note (as a System.Drawing.Color)

remarks.para: When the object color is set, NX will not necessarily honor the request. NX chooses the color from its current color table that is closest to the requested color.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.AspectRatio

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.LineAngle

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Note.IsVertical
member.summary: If true, indicates that the text will be oriented vertically, not horizontally
member.remarks:
In "vertical" text, the characters are still upright, but are arranged in a vertical column. If you want to take a line of text and simply rotate it into a vertical position, you should
set LineAngle equal to plus or minus 90 degrees.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.NXObject
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.NXObject object (interchangeable with NXOpen.NxObject)
member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.NXObject class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.NXOpenTaggedObject
member.summary: The enclosed NXOpen.TaggedObject of this NX.NXObject

remarks.para: A SNAP object is just a simple wrapper around a corresponding NX Open object for example, a Snap.NX.Spline object is just a wrapper that encloses an NXOpen.Spline, and a Snap.NX.Sphere is a wrapper around an NXOpen.Features.Sphere object, and so on. So, if you have an NXOpen object, you can wrap it to create a Snap.NX object. In the other direction, if you have a Snap.NX object, you can unwrap it to get the NXOpen object that it encloses.

There are hidden implicit conversions that do this wrapping and unwrapping for you, so often things just work without any extra effort. However, there are times when the implicit conversions dont work, and you need to do something more explicit. For example, if you want to use NXOpen member functions or properties, then you have to get an NXOpen object from your SNAP object first.
Chapter 16 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide has a section entitled "Mixing SNAP and NX/Open" that discusses this topic in more detail.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.NXOpenTag
member.summary: Get the NXOpen.Tag from this NX.NXObject

members.member:
Tests whether this NXObject is "equal to" another NXObject The other NXObject to be used in the equality test Returns True if this object is equal to the other one
Two NXObject instances are regarded as equal if their enclosed NXOpen objects are equal (which means that the NXOpen objects have the same tag).
Note that "equal" here is only loosely related to the geometry of the object. If two Point objects are "equal", for example, then they will certainly have the same coordinates, but the converse is not true.
Your code may be more readable if you use the = operator or the <> operator to check whether two NXObject items are equal, as in the example below.
The following example shows various diffent equality situations and tests:
The = operator or The <> operator

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Equals(System.Object)
member.summary: Over-rides the System.Object.Equals method
member.param: The other object to be used in the equality test
member.returns: Returns True if this object is equal to the other one

remarks.para: Equality is True if the other object is of type NXObject, and is equal to this object based on the NXObject.Equals method.
Please refer to NXObject.Equals for a discussion of what it means for two NXObject items to be "equal".

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.ObjectType
member.summary: The type of the object

remarks.para: Note that SNAP object types are somewhat different from NX/Open ones. The biggest difference is in the area of bodies, faces, and edges. In NX/Open these all have type = UF_solid_type, but in SNAP there are three separate types: NX.ObjectTypes.Type.Body, NX.ObjectTypes.Type.Face, and NX.ObjectTypes.Type.Edge.
Also, we have specific types for the SNAP DatumPlane and DatumAxis objects, whereas the corresponding NXOpen objects are just "features".

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.IsAlive(NXOpen.TaggedObject)
member.summary: If true, indicates that the enclosed NXOpen object is "alive"

remarks.para: Returns "False" if the input object is null.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.ObjectSubType
member.summary: The subtype of the object

remarks.para: Note that SNAP object subtypes are somewhat different from NX/Open ones.

One difference is in the area of bodies, face, and edges. In SNAP, these are three different object types, and their subtypes provide useful information about their geometry. For example the Body type has subtypes BodySolid and BodySheet, the Face type has subtypes FacePlane and FaceCone, and so on.

Another difference is that SNAP subtypes are unique, so you can use them alone, without considering object types. So, for example, the expression myCurve.ObjectSubtype = NX.ObjectTypes.SubType.ConicEllipse will be true if and only if myCurve is an ellipse. There is no need to do a separate check to see if it is a conic.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.HasDisplayProperties
member.summary: If true, indicates (roughly) that this object is displayable

remarks.para: In fact, the HasDisplayProperties property is true if and only if the object's NXOpenDisplayableObjects array has length greater than zero.
So, then, you may get and set display properties like layer and color.

If HasDisplayProperties is True, this is not quite the same thing as saying that the object is itself displayable. For example, a cone feature is not displayable, but it will have HasDisplayProperties = True because display properties can be obtained from the associated solid body (which is a displayable object).

member.example: This example shows how you might use this property:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.NXOpenDisplayableObjects
member.summary: The associated NXOpen.DisplayableObjects of this NX.NXObject

remarks.para: Usually, this is just an array of length one containing the enclosed NXOpenTaggedObject. But, in the case of a feature, this definition needs to be over-ridden, so we declare it Overridable here.
There are some objects (like layer categories, for example) that have no corresponding displayable objects. In these cases, this function returns an array of length zero.
You can use the HasDisplayProperties property to check whether an object has any associated displayable objects.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.NXOpenDisplayableObject
member.summary: The associated NXOpen.DisplayableObject of this NX.NXObject

remarks.para: Usually, this is just the enclosed NXOpenTaggedObject, but, in the case of a features, this definition needs to be over-ridden, so we declare it Overridable here.
The returned value will be Nothing if there is no corresponding displayable object.
Unless it's Nothing, the NXOpenDisplayableObject property always has the same value as NXOpenDisplayableObjects[0], so it's just a convenience shortcut.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.Layer
member.summary: The layer on which the object resides

remarks.para: If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the Layer property will raise an exception.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.LineWidth
member.summary: The line width used to draw the object (thin, medium, or thick)

remarks.para: If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the LineWidth property will raise an exception.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.LineFont
member.summary: The line font used to draw the object (solid, dashed, etc.)

remarks.para: If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the LineFont property will raise an exception.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.Color
member.summary: The color of the object (as a System.Drawing.Color)

remarks.para: When the object color is set, NX will not necessarily honor the request. NX chooses the color from its current color table that is closest to the requested color.
If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the Color property will raise an exception.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

members.member:
The translucency of the object
The translucency value is an integer between 0 and 100. A value of 0 indicates that the object is completely opaque (no translucency at all). A value of 100 indicates that the object is completely translucent, and therefore invisible.
The setting only has a visible effect if the object is a body (solid or sheet) or a facetted body.
If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the Translucency property will raise an exception.
This object is of a type that has no display properties.>

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.IsHidden
member.summary: If true, indicates that the object is hidden (blanked)

remarks.para: If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the IsHidden property will raise an exception.
You can hide an object by setting its IsHidden property to True, and Show it by setting IsHidden = False.
If you want to Hide or Show several objects, it may be more convenient to use the Hide and Show functions.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.IsHighlighted
member.summary: If true, indicates that the displayable object is highlighted

remarks.para: If the object's HasDisplayProperties property is False, then getting or setting the IsHighlighted property will raise an exception.

member.exception: This object is of a type that has no display properties.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.Box
member.summary: The bounding box of the object

remarks.para: The Box property is implemented only for curves, edges, faces, bodies, features, and components. For other object types, getting the property will return Nothing, and will throw a System.ArgumentException.

member.exception: The input object is not of a type that can be boxed

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.Name
member.summary: The name of the object (also called "custom name")

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.NameLocation
member.summary: The position at which the name of the object is displayed

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.IsOccurrence
member.summary: If true, indicates that this object is an occurrence.

remarks.para: Occurrences are created when a part is inserted into an assembly. The inserted part gives rise to a component in the assembly part, and each object in the inserted part gives rise to an occurrence. An occurrence object can be regarded as a "proxy" for the corresponding object in the inserted part (which is called its "prototype").
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concept of occurrences.

member.example: The following example shows the use of the IsOccurrence property:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.NXObject.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype object of this object (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the object is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.example: The following example shows the use of the Prototype property:

members.member:
Returns the owning component of this object (if it has one)
Only occurrence objects have an owning component, so this property returns Nothing if the object is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.
Occurrences are created when a part is inserted into an assembly. In the assembly, the inserted part gives rise to a component, and each object in the inserted part gives rise to an object occurrence. The component is said to be the "owner" of the object occurrences, and they are said to be its "members".
See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concept of occurrences.
IsOccurrence property Snap.NX.Component

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.CreateNXObject(NXOpen.TaggedObject)
member.summary: Creates an NX.NXObject of the most specific type possible
member.returns: An NX.NXObject which has the most specific type possible

remarks.para: The returned object's static type is still NX.NXObject, but, where possible, the NX.NXObject variable now contains an object whose run-time type is more specific, so that it can be successfully cast to that more specific type by the caller. This is used in Selection, for example.
This function should be used instead of the NX.NXObject constructors, to guarantee that properly downcast objects are created whenever possible.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.CreateNXObject2(NXOpen.TaggedObject)
member.summary: Creates an NX.NXObject of the most specific type possible
member.returns: An NX.NXObject which has the most specific type possible

remarks.para: Same as CreateNXObject, except that this function ... creates a Snap.NX.DatumPlane when given the tag of an NXOpen.DatumPlane, and it creates a Snap.NX.DatumAxis when given the tag of an NXOpen.DatumAxis. This behaviour is useful when returning selection results. If we didn't do this, the object returned from Selection would be a generic Snap.NX.NXObject enclosing an NXOpen.DatumPlane, which is not very useful to the caller.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Copy
member.summary: Copies an NX.NXObject (with no transform)
member.returns: A copy of the input object

remarks.para: The new object will be on the same layer as the original one.

member.exception: The object is an edge. Edges cannot be copied.
The object is a face. Faces cannot be copied.
A feature cannot be copied unless all of its ancestors are copied too.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Copy(Snap.Geom.Transform)
member.summary: Transforms/copies an object
member.exception: The object is an edge. Edges cannot be copied.
The object is a face. Faces cannot be copied.
A feature cannot be copied unless all of its ancestors are copied too.
A transform that does not preserve angles cannot be applied to a coordinate system.

remarks.para: To create a transformation, use the functions in the Snap.Geom.Transform class.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Copy(Snap.NX.NXObject[])
member.summary: Copies an array of NX.NXObject (with no transform)
member.returns: A copy of the input objects

remarks.para: The new objects will be on the same layers as the original ones.

member.exception: One of the input objects is an edge. Edges cannot be copied.
One of the input objects is a face. Faces cannot be copied.
A feature cannot be copied unless all of its ancestors are copied too.

remarks.para: To create a transformation, use the functions in the Snap.Geom.Transform class.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Copy(Snap.Geom.Transform,Snap.NX.NXObject[])
member.summary: Transforms/copies an array of NX objects
member.returns: A copy of the input objects
member.exception: One of the input objects is an edge. Edges cannot be copied.
One of the input objects is a face. Faces cannot be copied.
A feature cannot be copied unless all of its ancestors are copied too.
A transform that does not preserve angles cannot be applied to a coordinate system.

remarks.para: To create a transformation, use the functions in the Snap.Geom.Transform class.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Move(Snap.Geom.Transform)
member.summary: Transform/Move an object
member.returns: Error code. If positive, this indicates a problem. See Remarks below for details.
member.exception: The object is an edge. Edges cannot be moved.
The object is a face. Faces cannot be moved.
A feature cannot be moved, because its position is controlled by its parents.

remarks.para: To create a transformation, use the functions in the Snap.Geom.Transform class.

The error code returned reports success or failure. If zero, it indicates that the Move operation was successful. If greater than zero, some problem arose, as described in the documentation for the function NXOpen.Ufs.Trns.TransformObjects (uf5947). Most error conditions are reported by raising exceptions, so this return value is not likely to be very useful.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Move(Snap.Geom.Transform,Snap.NX.NXObject[])
member.summary: Transform/Move an array of objects
member.exception: One of the input objects is an edge. Edges cannot be moved.
One of the input objects is a face. Faces cannot be moved.
A feature cannot be moved, because its position is controlled by its parents.

remarks.para: To create a transformation, use the functions in the Snap.Geom.Transform class.

member.summary: Find all the objects in the work part that have a given name
member.returns: An array of NX.NXObject objects having the given name

If there are no objects having the given name, the array will have length zero.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.FindByName(System.String)
member.summary: Find the first object in the work part that has a given name
member.returns: An NX.NXObject object having the given name

remarks.para: This function finds the first object in the work part that has the given name. If the work part contains several objects with the same name, the result will be unpredictable. In this case, you should use the FindAllByName function, instead.
The return will be Nothing if there are no objects in the work part that have the given name.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Hide(Snap.NX.NXObject[])

remarks.para: In former times, the "Hide" function was known as "Blank". Only the name has changed; the operation is exactly the same as before.
Another way to Hide an object is to set its IsHidden property to True.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Show(Snap.NX.NXObject[])
member.summary: Shows (Unblanks) an array of NXObject objects

remarks.para: In former times, the "Show" function was known as "Unblank". Only the name has changed; the operation is exactly the same as before.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.Wrap(NXOpen.Tag)
member.summary: Convert an NXOpen.NXObject tag to a Snap.NX.NXObject
member.param: The tag of an NXOpen.NXObject object to be converted
member.returns: The Snap.NX.NXObject object formed by wrapping the NXOpen.NXObject having the given tag

remarks.para: Returns Nothing if the input tag is NXOpen.Tag.Null, or is not the tag of an NXOpen.NXObject.
In many cases, you can just use an NXOpen object directly in SNAP functions, without wrapping. The main reason for wrapping is to allow use of the properties of the resulting SNAP object.
For more information about wrapping NXOpen objects, please see the section entitled "Mixing SNAP and NX Open" in the SNAP Getting Started Guide; it's the last section in chapter 16.

member.exception: The input tag is NXOpen.Tag.Null, or it doesn't belong to an NXOpen.NXObject object

member.name: M:Snap.NX.NXObject.GetAttributeStrings
member.summary: Get the object's attributes as strings
member.returns: An array of strings representing the object's attributes

remarks.para: This function returns a two-dimensional array of strings. If the object has n attributes, this array will have dimensions n × 3.

If the returned array is called attribStrings, then the three elements in the i-th row are:
attribStrings(i,0) -- the type of the attribute, expressed as a string
attribStrings(i,1) -- the title of the attribute (always a string, anyway)
attribStrings(i,2) -- the value of the attribute, converted to string form

member.name: M:Snap.NX.OffsetCurve.CreateOffsetCurve(Snap.NX.ICurve[],Snap.Number,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Creates an offset curve feature from given curves, direction, distance
member.param: Array of curves to be offset
If true, reverse direction of offset. The default direction is the normal of the array of curves.

remarks.para: The resulting NX.OffsetCurve object may consist of many curves. Use the Curves property of this object to get the curves themselves.
This function doesn't accept a single line as input. Please us the function OffsetLine if you want to offset a single line.

member.example: This example shows how to create an offset curve:

member.param: Array of curves to be offset
If true, reverse direction of offset. The default direction is close to the normal of the array of curves.

remarks.para: The resulting NX.OffsetCurve object may consist of many curves. Use the Curves property of this object to get the curves themselves.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.OffsetCurve.CreateOffsetCurve(Snap.NX.ICurve[],Snap.Number,Snap.Position,Snap.Vector)
member.summary: Creates an offset curve feature from given curves, direction, distance
member.param: Array of base curves to be offset
A help point on the base curves
The offset direction (roughly) at the help point

remarks.para: The resulting NX.OffsetCurve object may consist of many curves. Use the Curves property of this object to get the curves themselves.
Offsets of lines and arcs will again be lines and arcs, respectively. Offsets of splines and ellipses will be splines that approximate the exact offsets to with DistanceTolerance.
This function doesn't accept an array consisting of a single line as input.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.OffsetCurve.Wrap(NXOpen.Tag)
member.summary: Convert an NXOpen.Features.OffsetCurve tag to a Snap.NX.OffsetCurve
member.param: The tag of an NXOpen.Features.OffsetCurve object to be converted
member.returns: The Snap.NX.OffsetCurve object formed by wrapping the NXOpen.Features.OffsetCurve having the given tag

remarks.para: In many cases, you can just use an NXOpen object directly in SNAP functions, without wrapping. The main reason for wrapping is to allow use of the properties of the resulting SNAP object.
For more information about wrapping NXOpen objects, please see the section entitled "Mixing SNAP and NX Open" in the SNAP Getting Started Guide; it's the last section in chapter 16.

member.exception: The input tag is NXOpen.Tag.Null, or it doesn't belong to an NXOpen.Features.OffsetCurve object

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Part
member.summary: Represents an NX.Part object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Part)

remarks.para: To create an NX.Part object, use the Snap.Create.Part functions.

An NX.Part object provides various arrays that allow you to cycle through the objects it contains. For example, the Part.Bodies array contains all the bodies in the part, the Part.Expressions array contains all expressions, and so on. The Part.Objects array contains all objects in the part, of all types.

member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Part class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.NXOpenPart
member.summary: The enclosed NXOpen.Part object

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.NXOpenTag
member.summary: The NXOpen.Tag of the enclosed NXOpen.Part object

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.Features
member.summary: An array containing all the NX.Feature objects in this part

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.Objects
member.summary: An array containing all the NX.NXObject objects in this part
member.remarks:
The returned array contains all the objects in the part, including many that SNAP knows nothing about (like cameras, light-sources, and skeleton objects).
Also, the array contains "occurrences". These are objects that are merely links to "real" objects that actually reside in subassemblies, rather than in the current part.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.
To cycle through objects of a specific type, you should use other properties of the Part object. For example, to cycle through all bodies, use the Part.Bodies array, rather than the Part.Objects array.
member.example: This example shows how to use the Part.Objects array:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.Points
member.summary: An array containing all the NX.Point objects in this part

remarks.para: Note that this array does not include points that are occurrences. To find all points in a part, including occurrences, please use its Objects collection.

member.example: This example shows how to cycle through the points in a part:

members.member:
The name of the part
The string returned depends on whether you are running in native or managed mode. You can determine the current mode by using the Snap.Globals.ManagedMode property.
In native mode (ManagedMode = False), the result is the operating system filename, with extension, which is typically something like engine.prt
In managed mode (ManagedMode = True), the result is a combination of the Teamcenter part number and revision level, separated by a "/" character, so typically something like engine/A.
> Snap.NX.Part.FullPath

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Part.FullPath
member.summary: Full pathname of the part, including extension

remarks.para:
The string returned depends on whether you are running in native or managed mode. You can determine the current mode by using the Snap.Globals.ManagedMode property.
In native mode (ManagedMode = False), the result is the operating system pathname, typically something like C:\parts\engine.prt
In managed mode (ManagedMode = True), the result is the CLI name of the part, which is a combination of the Teamcenter part number and revision level, with the prefix @DB/. So, typically, this looks something like @DB/engine/A.

remarks.para: The input string can be either the name of the part, as returned by the Snap.NX.Part.Name property, or the pathname of the part, as obtained from the Snap.NX.Part.FullPath property

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Part.Close(System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Close the part
member.param: Indicates which parts in subassemblies should be closed
Indicates whether modified parts should be closed

remarks.para:
The meaning of the "CloseWholeTree" argument is as follows:
If true, all parts in the assembly tree are closed, including this part and all subassembly parts
If false, only this part is closed

The meaning of the "CloseModified" argument is as follows:
If true, it will close all modified parts
If false, it does not close any modified parts

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Part.GetAttributeStrings
member.summary: Get the object's attributes as strings
member.returns: An array of strings representing the object's attributes

remarks.para: This function returns a two-dimensional array of strings. If the object has n attributes, this array will have dimensions n × 3.

If the returned array is called attribStrings, then the three elements in the i-th row are:
attribStrings(i,0) -- the type of the attribute, expressed as a string
attribStrings(i,1) -- the title of the attribute (always a string, anyway)
attribStrings(i,2) -- the value of the attribute, converted to string form

member.example: The following example illustrates the use of this function:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Point.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype point of this point (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if the point is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Spline
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Spline object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Spline)

remarks.para:
The representation used here consists of
Knots -- An array of n+k knot values : t[0], ... , t[n+k-1]
Poles -- An array of n 3D positions representing poles (control vertices)
Weights -- An array of n weight values
The order and degree of the curve can be inferred from the sizes of these arrays. If we let
n = number of poles = Poles.Length (or Weights.Length)
npk = n+k = number of knots = Knots.Length
Then Order = k = npk - n, and as usual, Degree = Order - 1
To create an NX.Spline object, use the Snap.Create.Spline functions.

member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Spline class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.NXOpenSpline
member.summary: The enclosed NXOpen.Spline object

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Geometry
member.summary: The geometric data of the spline curve
member.example: The following example shows how to use this property:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Poles
member.summary: Array of 3D positions representing poles (control points)
member.remarks: There will be n poles, with indices 0,1,2,...,n-1

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Weights
member.summary: Array of values representing weights

remarks.para: There will be n weights, with indices 0,1,2,...,n-1. The weights must be strictly positive. This is not checked.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Degree
member.summary: The degree of the spline, m (equal to order - 1)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Order
member.summary: The order of the spline, k (equal to degree + 1)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Knots
member.summary: Array of knot values
member.remarks: There will be n+k knots, with indices 0,1,2,...,n+k-1, where k = Order

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Spline.Prototype
member.summary: Returns the prototype spline of this one (if it has one)

remarks.para: The prototype of an occurrence object is the source object that supplies the data of the occurrence. See chapter 11 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an introduction to assembly modeling, including the concepts of prototypes and occurrences.
Only occurrence objects have prototypes, so this property returns Nothing if this spline is not an occurrence.
You can determine whether an object is an occurrence by using its IsOccurrence property.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Spline.Divide
member.summary: Divide a spline into segments at its knots
member.remarks:
The function will create new splines by dividing the original one.
Each of the new splines will be a Bezier curve (a spline with only one segment).
member.example: This example shows how to divide a spline at its knots:

member.name: T:Snap.NX.TextStyle
member.summary: An object describing the style (font, color, etc.) of text

remarks.para: TextStyle objects are used to specify the properties of text used in notes and in drawing temporary text

member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the TextStyle class:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.Color
member.summary: The color of the text

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.FontIndex
member.summary: The index of the font within the part file's font table

remarks.para: It is this index that actually determines the font used to display the note, not the font name. Therefore, if the entries in the font table are re-organized, a different font may be used, so the appearance of the text will change.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.FontName
member.summary: The name of the primary font

remarks.para: When setting this property, we first try to find a system (TrueType) font with the given name. If this fails, we look for a traditional NX font, instead. If you want more control over the search process, please use the SetFont function, instead.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.TextStyle.SetFont(System.String,Snap.NX.TextStyle.FontType)
member.summary: Sets the primary font for text
member.param: The name of the font to be used
The type of font (either a standard system font or an NX font)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.StrokeWidth
member.summary: The width (thickness) of the strokes used to draw the font
member.remarks: This only makes sense for old-style NX fonts, not system (Truetype) fonts.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.FontSize
member.summary: The font size (in points)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.FontStyle
member.summary: The style of the text (bold, italic, etc.)

remarks.para: To find out which styles are supported by a given font, use the Windows Font control panel. As you will see, most fonts include the styles "Regular", "Bold", Italic", and "Bold Italic". But, with some fonts, more exotic style names are used. For example, the Lucida Sans font has a style called "Demibold Roman".

member.name: F:Snap.NX.TextStyle.NxFontSize
member.summary: The font size, expressed in part units (mm or inches)

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.CharSpaceFactor
member.summary: A multiplier used to adjust the spacing between characters

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.AspectRatio
member.summary: A multiplier used to adjust the shapes of characters. Values greater than 1 will make characters wider than normal.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.LineSpaceFactor
member.summary: A multiplier used to adjust the spacing between lines of text

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.HorizontalTextJustification
member.summary: The horizontal justification of the text (left, center, or right)
member.remarks: This takes effect only when the text has two or more lines

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.AlignmentPosition
member.summary: One of nine "sites" used to locate the text
member.example: The following example creates notes with different alignment types:

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.LineAngle
member.summary: The angle between the baseline of the text and the horizontal

member.name: P:Snap.NX.TextStyle.IsVertical
member.summary: If true, indicates that the text will be oriented vertically, not horizontally
member.remarks:
In "vertical" text, the characters are still upright, but are arranged in a vertical column. If you want to take a line of text and simply rotate it into a vertical position, you should
set LineAngle equal to plus or minus 90 degrees.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.TextStyle.#ctor

member.remarks: The properties of the text are obtained from the settings in Annotation Preferences

member.name: T:Snap.NX.TextStyle.TextJustification

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Torus
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Torus object (a special kind of NX.Revolved object) (interchangeable with NXOpen.Features.Revolve)

remarks.para: To create an NX.Torus object, use the Snap.Create.Torus functions.
A torus is formed by rotating a circle around an axis that lies in its plane. Torus shapes can look quite different, depending on the relative values of the MinorRadius and MajorRadius properties.

list.item: If MinorRadius < MajorRadius, then a donut shape is produced.
If MinorRadius > Abs(MajorRadius) and MajorRadius > 0, we get an "apple" shape.
If MinorRadius > Abs(MajorRadius) and MajorRadius < 0, we get a "lemon" or "barrel" shape.

member.example: This example shows how to use the properties of the NX.Torus class:

member.summary: Axis point

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Torus.AxisVector
member.summary: Axis vector

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Torus.MajorRadius
member.summary: Major radius. The radius of the "spine" circle, which can be either positive or negative

member.name: P:Snap.NX.Torus.MinorRadius
member.summary: Minor radius. The radius of the "section" circle, which must be positive.

member.name: M:Snap.NX.Torus.#ctor(NXOpen.Features.Revolve)
member.summary: Constructor, given an NXOpen.Features.Revolve object

member.summary: Creates a toroidal surface, given center, matrix, major radius, minor radius, and parameter limits
member.param: Orientation of the torus. AxisZ is the axis of revolution
The UV parameter box of the surface (MinU, MinV, MaxU, MaxV)

member.param: Vector along axis of revolution (length doesn't matter)

member.name: T:Snap.NX.Unit
member.summary: Represents a Snap.NX.Unit object (interchangeable with NXOpen.Unit)

remarks.para: The most common way to obtain a Snap.NX.Unit object is to simply get the length unit of the work part. You can do this using the Snap.Globals.PartUnit property.
Alternatively, there are "constant" units called Snap.NX.Unit.Millimeter, Snap.NX.Unit.Inch, Snap.NX.Unit.Degree, and Snap.NX.Unit.Radian.
