member.name: M:Snap.NX.Unit.Wrap(NXOpen.Tag)
member.summary: Convert an NXOpen.Unit tag to a Snap.NX.Unit
member.param: The tag of an NXOpen.Unit object to be converted
member.returns: The Snap.NX.Unit object formed by wrapping the NXOpen.Unit having the given tag

remarks.para: In many cases, you can just use an NXOpen object directly in SNAP functions, without wrapping. The main reason for wrapping is to allow use of the properties of the resulting SNAP object.
For more information about wrapping NXOpen objects, please see the section entitled "Mixing SNAP and NX Open" in the SNAP Getting Started Guide; it's the last section in chapter 16.

member.exception: The input tag is NXOpen.Tag.Null, or it doesn't belong to an NXOpen.Unit object

member.name: T:Snap.NX.View.Standard
member.summary: A class containing standard or "canned" views (top, front, right, etc.)

remarks.para: These views are present in every NX part file, and they cannot be deleted or renamed.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Top
member.summary: The standard or "canned" top view

remarks.para:
This view has
The X-axis pointing from left to right
The Y-axis pointing upwards
The Z-axis pointing out of the screen

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Front
member.summary: The standard or "canned" front view

remarks.para:
This view has
The X-axis pointing from left to right
The Z-axis pointing upwards
The Y-axis pointing out of the screen

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Right
member.summary: The standard or "canned" right side view

remarks.para:
This view has
The Y-axis pointing from left to right
The Z-axis pointing upwards

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Back

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Bottom

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Isometric
member.summary: The standard or "canned" isometric view

remarks.para: This is an isometric view in which the top, front, and right-hand faces of the object are visible. The Z-axis appears to be vertical, in this view.

member.name: P:Snap.NX.View.Standard.Trimetric
member.summary: The standard or "canned" trimetric view

remarks.para: This is a trimetric view in which the top, front, and right-hand faces of the object are visible. The Z-axis appears to be vertical, in this view.

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Fin
member.summary: A fin is "half" of an edge -- an oriented use of an edge by a loop

remarks.para:
A fin has:
A logical 'sense' indicating whether the fin's orientation, and therefore the orientation of its owning loop, is the same as its owning edge
A curve, which may be Nothing if geometry is attached to the fin's edge, instead.
In some software systems, fins are called "half-edges" or "co-edges".
The picture below shows the fins and edges on three faces of a cube. The thick blue lines are edges, and the thin red ones are fins.

Note how each edge has two corresponding fins, which have opposite senses. On the vertical edge, E3, for example, fin F4 has a positive sense (i.e. the same direction as E3), and fin F5 has a negative sense.

Within each loop, the fins have a consistent direction, and, when walking along the loop in this direction, the loop's face lies on your left. In simple cases, this means that peripheral loops will have a counterclockwise direction, and hole loops will have a clockwise direction, when viewed from outside the body.
The red vertex is the start vertex of fins F2, F3 and F5, and it is the end vertex of fins F1, F4, and F6.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Body
member.summary: The body on which this fin lies

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Loop
member.summary: The loop to which this fin belongs

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Face
member.summary: The face to which this fin belongs

remarks.para: Actually, the relationship between the fin and the face is indirect: the fin belongs to a loop, and that loop then belongs to a face. This property just provides a shortcut that allows you to get to the face in one step instead of two.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Edge
member.summary: The edge to which this fin belongs

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Next
member.summary: The next fin in the loop

remarks.para: You can use this function to cycle through the fins in a loop, one at a time, in the "forward" direction (i.e. in the order returned by Snap.Topology.Loop.Fins. The ordering is cyclic, so the first fin is returned again after the last one.
If there is only one fin in the loop, then this property returns the current fin.

member.example: The following example creates a Widget object and cycles through the fins of one of its loops..

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Previous
member.summary: The previous fin in the loop

remarks.para: You can use this function to cycle through the fins in a loop, one at a time, in the "reverse" direction (i.e. the opposite of the order returned by Snap.Topology.Loop.Fins. The ordering is cyclic, so the last fin is returned again after the first one.
If there is only one fin in the loop, then this property returns the current fin.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.Sense
member.summary: The sense of the fin with respect to its owning edge

remarks.para: If a given edge has two fins, then these two fins will have opposite senses.
The fin sense allows you to determine the "forward" direction of the fin and its loop. This is important because you can then find the "left" side of the fin, which is where its face lies.

member.example: In the following example, we use the fin sense to construct a vector that points to the left of the fin, into the interior of its face.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.StartVertex
member.summary: The start vertex of the fin

remarks.para:
There are three possible cases:
If the fin has no vertices, this property returns Nothing
If the fin has one vertex (because its start and end points are coincident), then this property returns the common start/end vertex. This case is rare.
If the fin has two vertices, this property returns the one that is shared by this fin and the previous fin in the loop.

member.example: The following example creates a Widget object and gets the start and end vertices of the fins in one of its loops.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Fin.EndVertex
member.summary: The end vertex of the fin

remarks.para:
There are three possible cases:
If the fin has no vertices, this property returns Nothing
If the fin has one vertex (because its start and end points are coincident), then this property returns the common start/end vertex. This case is rare.
If the fin has two vertices, this property returns the one that is shared by this fin and the next fin in the loop.

member.name: M:Snap.Topology.Fin.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the fin
member.returns: A string containing the object type and its Parasolid tag

remarks.para: Returns an empty zero-length string if this object is Nothing

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Loop
member.summary: A loop is a connected sequence of fins that form part of the boundary of a face

remarks.para: Typically, a face will have one peripheral loop and perhaps some hole loops in its interior.

Within each loop, the fins have a consistent direction, and, when walking along the loop in this direction, the loop's face lies on your left. In simple cases, this means that peripheral loops will have a counterclockwise direction, and hole loops will have a clockwise direction, when viewed from outside the body.
Note that you can not use "loop" as the name of a variable in your code, because it is a reserved word in the Visual Basic language.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Body
member.summary: The body on which this loop lies

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Face
member.summary: The face on which this loop lies

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Vertices
member.summary: The array of vertices in the loop

remarks.para: If the loop has no vertices (a loop containing a single circular edge, for example), this property will return an array of length zero.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Fins
member.summary: The array of fins in the loop

remarks.para: The fins are ordered nose-to-tail around the loop, so that the end of each fin coincides with the beginning of the next fin in the list, and the end of the last fin coincides with the start of the first one.
If you were to walk along the fin, with the face normal pointing from your feet up towards your head, then the face that owns the fin would be on your left.
If you prefer to get the fins of a loop one at a time, rather than getting them all at once, you can use the Next or Previous properties to cycle through them.

member.example: The following example creates a Widget object and gets information about the fins in the outer loop of one of its faces..

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Edges
member.summary: The array of edges in the loop

remarks.para: There are cases where a loop has no edges. For example, at the tip of cone, there is a loop that contains one vertex and zero edges. In this case, this function will return an array with length zero.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Loop.Type
member.summary: The type of the loop (peripheral, hole, etc.)

member.name: M:Snap.Topology.Loop.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the loop
member.returns: A string containing the object type and its Parasolid tag

remarks.para: Returns an empty zero-length string if this object is Nothing

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Shell
member.summary: A shell is a connected set of faces forming part of the boundary of a body

remarks.para: Two faces can belong to the same shell only if they are "connected" in the sense that they share a common edge.
A typical solid body has a single outer shell and perhaps some inner shells that define internal voids.

members.member: The array of faces in the shell> Snap.NX.Face

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Shell.Type
member.summary: The type of the shell (Outer, Inner, or Open)

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Shell.Body
member.summary: The body that contains this shell

member.name: M:Snap.Topology.Shell.ToString
member.summary: Returns a string representation of the shell
member.returns: A string containing the object type and its Parasolid tag

remarks.para: Returns an empty zero-length string if this object is Nothing

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Sense
member.summary: A plus/minus value used to indicate the sense of a Face, Edge, or Fin.

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.Sense.Positive
member.summary: The items are aligned (they have the same sense)

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.Sense.Negative
member.summary: The items are anti-aligned (they have opposite senses)

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.ShellType
member.summary: The type of a Shell object.

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.ShellType.Outer
member.summary: The shell represents the exterior surface of a solid body

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.ShellType.Inner
member.summary: The shell represents a void inside a solid body

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.ShellType.Open
member.summary: The shell represents a sheet body

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.LoopType
member.summary: The type of a Loop object.

remarks.para: For planes and other non-periodic surfaces, all loops are either of type Outer or Inner. Each face has one peripheral loop (type Outer) and possibly some holes (type Inner).

For cylindrical topology, i.e. surfaces that are periodic in one parameter direction only, closed loops that wind once around the periodic parameter space are of type Winding. To define the periphery of a face in this situation, you need either an Outer loop or a matched pair of Winding loops.
A winding loop that completely surrounds the tip (singularity) of a cone has type InnerSingular.
On spheres and donut tori, it is sometimes not clear whether a loop represents a periphery or a hole. This is the reason for the loop types LikelyOuter, LikelyInner, and Unknown.

member.example: The following example creates a Widget object and lists its loop types

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.Outer
member.summary: A simple peripheral loop

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.Inner
member.summary: A simple hole loop

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.Winding
member.summary: A winding loop on a periodic surface e.g. a circle on a cylinder or doughnut

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.InnerSingular
member.summary: A hole loop around a surface singularity, e.g. chopping the top off a cone

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.LikelyOuter
member.summary: An apparently peripheral loop on a doubly closed surface

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.LikelyInner
member.summary: An apparent hole in a doubly closed surface

member.name: F:Snap.Topology.LoopType.Unknown
member.summary: Unknown loop type

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Topo
member.summary: An abstract class representing any topology object

remarks.para: You will probably never use a Topo object directly. Instead, you will use more concrete objects like fins, loops, shells, and vertices, which inherit from the Topo class.

In some sense, Snap.NX.Face and Snap.NX.Edge objects also represent "topology". But the Snap.NX objects are persistent (stored in NX part files), whereas the Snap.Topology objects are transient. As soon as your SNAP program has finished executing, all of your fins, loops, shells, and vertices are gone.

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains objects and functions that help you get detailed information about the topology of a body (how the faces and edges are connected to each other).

remarks.para: You can do basic topological enquiries using the Snap.NX.Face and Snap.NX.Edge objects. But the Loop, Fin, and Vertex objects here in the Topology namespace allow you to get more detailed information.

member.name: T:Snap.Topology.Vertex
member.summary: A vertex is a place where several edges meet

remarks.para:
An edge may have zero, one, or two vertices.
An edge with zero vertices is a closed ring shape. Its start and end points coincide, and the start/end junction is smooth. Examples are edges E1 and E2 in the image below.
An edge with one vertex is again a closed ring shape whose start and end points coincide. But it has a distinct corner at the start/end junction point. Examples are edges E3 and E4 in the image below.
An edge with two vertices is open; its start and end points are different. An example is edge E5 in the image below.
Edges with one vertex are fairly unusual; most edges have either zero or two vertices.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Vertex.Body
member.summary: The body on which this vertex lies

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Vertex.Shell
member.summary: The shell that the vertex belongs to

remarks.para: In NX objects, a vertex always belongs to exactly one shell.

member.name: P:Snap.Topology.Vertex.Faces
member.summary: The faces on which the vertex lies

remarks.para: A vertex might lie on one, two, or more faces. The most common situation is a vertex lying on three faces.

member.example: This example shows how to cycle through vertices, finding the faces that meet at each one:

member.summary: The edges on which the vertex lies

remarks.para: A vertex might lie on zero, one, two, or more edges.
If the vertex lies on zero edges, this property will return an array of length zero.

member.example: This example shows how to get the edges meeting at each vertex:

member.name: T:Snap.UI.BlockDialog
member.summary: The SNAP class representing an NX Block-Based Dialog

remarks.para: A Snap.UI.BlockDialog is very similar to an NXOpen.BlockStyler.BlockDialog. You use the NX Block UI Styler application to place blocks on these dialogs and set the properties of these blocks.
Please see Chapter 13 and Chapter 14 of the "Getting Started with SNAP" guide for more information about BlockDialogs.
SNAP also provides another type of block-based dialog, called a Snap.UI.BlockForm, which you can create without using Block UI Styler.

SNAP also provides another type of block-based dialog, called a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, which you create using the NX Block UI Styler application.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.BlockForm.OnApply
member.summary: The BlockForm's callback function for the "Apply" event

remarks.para: This callback function is executed when the user clicks on the Apply button in your dialog.
You should over-ride this function with your own version, which should contain the code you want to have executed when the Apply event occurs.
For more information about how to use BlockForm callbacks, please refer to chapter 13 and chapter 14 in the SNAP Getting Started Guide.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.BlockForm.OnOK
member.summary: The BlockForm's callback function for the "OK" event

remarks.para: This callback function is executed when the user clicks on the OK button in your dialog.
You should over-ride this function with your own version, which should contain the code you want to have executed when the OK event occurs.
For more information about how to use BlockForm callbacks, please refer to chapter 13 and chapter 14 in the SNAP Getting Started Guide.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.BlockForm.OnCancel
member.summary: The BlockForm's callback function for the "Cancel" event

remarks.para: This callback function is executed when the user clicks on the Cancel button in your dialog.
You should over-ride this function with your own version, which should contain the code you want to have executed when the Cancel event occurs.
For more information about how to use BlockForm callbacks, please refer to chapter 13 and chapter 14 in the SNAP Getting Started Guide.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.BlockForm.OnUpdate(Snap.UI.Block.General)
member.summary: Update callback function
member.param: The block in which the user made a change

remarks.para: This callback function is executed when the user changes some value in some block on your BlockForm.
You should over-ride this function with your own version, which should contain the code you want to have executed when the change occurs.
Typically, your code will first test the parameter, to find out which block it is, and then react accordingly.
For more information about how to use BlockForm callbacks, please refer to chapter 13 and chapter 14 in the SNAP Getting Started Guide.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.BlockForm.OnShow
member.summary: The BlockForm's callback function for the "Show" event

remarks.para: This callback function is executed immediately before your BlockForm is shown (displayed to the user).
You should over-ride this function with your own version, which should contain the code you want to have executed when the Show event occurs.

Execution of the code in this function is the last thing that happens before your BlockForm is displayed, so it gives you one last chance to over-ride values and settings in the dialog. Specifically, you can over-write values that were retrieved from "dialog memory", if you want to.
For more information about how to use BlockForm callbacks, please refer to chapter 13 and chapter 14 in the SNAP Getting Started Guide.

member.returns: The name we invented. Names look like [inputBlock.Type]nnn, where nnn is a count. E.g. Button3, ListBox5

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Selection.Result
member.summary: The result returned from showing a selection dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Selection.Result.Objects
member.summary: The selected objects (possibly zero or one)

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Selection.Result.Object
member.summary: The first selected object. Always equal to Objects[0]

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Selection.Result.Response
member.summary: The user's response
member.remarks:
The possible values of the response are:
Back -- the user clicked the "Back" button
Cancel -- the user clicked the "Cancel" button
Ok -- the user clicked the "OK" button
ObjectSelectedByName -- the user selected an object by entering its name
ObjectSelected -- the user selected an object using the mouse

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Selection.Result.CursorRay
member.summary: The cursor ray

remarks.para: You can think of selection as a process of shooting an infinite line (the cursor ray) at your model. The object that gets selected is one that this ray hits, or the one that's closest to the ray. Sometimes, rather than just knowing which object was selected, you want to know where on the object the user clicked. You can figure this out by using the cursor ray. For example, you can find out where the ray intersects the model, or you can find out which end of a curve is closest to the ray. An example in chapter 15 of the SNAP "Getting Started" guide gives the details.
In some situations (like selecting by rectangle, selecting by name, or selecting multiple objects) the Selection.Result returned will have its CursorRay set to Nothing.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Selection.Result.PickPoint
member.summary: The cursor position at selected object

remarks.para: The "pick point" is a point on the selected object. It is either the place where the cursor ray pierces the object, or the closest point of the object to the cursor ray. Please see chapter 15 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an explanation of the cursor ray.
If the user selects multiple objects, the PickPoint property will have the value Nothing.

If you want a selection block on a dialog, rather than a standalone selection dialog, please use a Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject object.

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.NamespaceDoc
member.summary: Contains classes for various types of dialog blocks

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.General
member.summary: Abstract class to serve as the base class for other block (interchangeable with NXOpen.BlockStyler.UIBlock)

member.name: F:Snap.UI.Block.General.PropertyDictionary
member.summary: The property dictionary for this block

remarks.para: The dictionary serves as a temporary storage area for block properties, during the time period before the "real" NX/Open block exists. Once the NX/Open block does exist, properties are copied into it from the dictionary. Within the dictionary, the keys are {Type, Name} pairs. We call this pair a "PropertyKey". -- The "Type" of a property indicates which NX/Open function is used to access it -- The "Name" is the magic string that's passed to the NX/Open access function Note that the Name alone is not enough to identify the property. For example, an Enumeration block has three properties that all have the name "Value". The string "Value" gets passed to three different access functions to get three different property values. Note that examining dictionary contents in the Visual Studio debugger is complicated. You use: dictionary object -> Keys -> Non-Public members -> dictionary -> Non-Public members -> entries -> [0]

member.name: F:Snap.UI.Block.General.privateName
member.summary: A cached name, needed in situations where neither the Property Dictionary nor the associated NXOpen block exists. This can happen in initialize_cb following an "Apply", for example. member.summary: Copies property data from this block's Property Dictionary into fields of the NX/Open block

remarks.para: This can only be done after the NX/Open block comes into existence, of course.

member.name: M:Snap.UI.Block.General.BlockToDictionary(Snap.UI.BlockForm)
member.summary: Copy property data back from the NXOpen block to the block's Property Dictionary

remarks.para: This copying is done when the user clicks Apply, to capture any changes that the user made in the dialog. In fact, we create a new dictionary object and then replace the old one.

members.member:
Creates a Snap.UI.Block.General object of the most specific type possible
The returned block's static type is still Snap.UI.Block.General, but, where possible, the Snap.UI.Block.General variable now contains a block object whose run-time type is more specific, so that it can be successfully cast to that more specific type by the caller.
This function should be used instead of the UI.Block constructors, to guarantee that properly downcast objects are created whenever possible.
uiBlockThe input NXOpen.BlockStyler.UIBlock A Snap.UI.Block.General object that has the most specific type possible

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.LabelBlock.HighQualityBitmap
member.summary: If true, indicates that a high-quality (24-bit) version of the Bitmap should be displayed

remarks.para: This property is relevant only when the Bitmap property uses the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap. If you use a bitmap file, instead, then this property has no effect.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.LabelBlock.Localize
member.summary: If true, indicates that the Label string should be replaced by a localized version

remarks.para: If the Label string matches an English string in the NX string localization database and the Localize property is "true", then the Label string is translated to the current locale language.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.LabelBlock.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.LabelBlock.BalloonTooltipLayout
member.summary: The location of the text with respect to the image in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:
Horizontal -- This is the default value. The text is placed to the right of the image.
Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.summary: Allows the user to enter/edit a String
member.example:
This example shows how to use a String block:
The following picture shows the dialog that is produced:

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Label
member.summary: Explanatory text to label this block on the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Enabled
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be sensitive (not grayed out) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Expanded
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be expanded (not collapsed) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.BeginGroup
member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

remarks.para: The new group will contain the current block and any subsequent ones that have BeginGroup = False.
The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. Please see the documentation for the Group block for further information.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.RetainValue
member.summary: If true, indicates that the values in the block should be retained from one use of the dialog to the next

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Localize
member.summary: If true, indicates that the Label string should be replaced by a localized version

remarks.para: If the Label string matches an English string in the NX string localization database and the Localize property is "true", then the Label string is translated to the current locale language.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.Value
member.summary: The string to be displayed/edited

remarks.para: Fully general Unicode strings are supported if AllowInternationalTextInput is set to "true" (which it always should be).

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.WideValue
member.summary: The string to be displayed/edited (ASCII only)

remarks.para: This property is available only when property "AllowInternationalTextInput" is true. Also, at any instance either this property or "Value" is available for the block.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.PresentationStyle
member.summary: The presentation style of the block (how it is displayed)

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.MaxTextLength
member.summary: The maximum number of characters accepted as input (integer between 1 and 1024)

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.ListItems
member.summary: Contains the list of items for list box

remarks.para: ListItems property will be available only if property PresentationStyle is List or Combo.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.ToolTip
member.summary: The tooltip text to be displayed when the user hovers the mouse pointer over the block

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.ReadOnly
member.summary: If true, indicates that the string cannot be modified

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.AllowInternationalTextInput
member.summary: If true, indicates that international text characters supported by NX will be allowed as input

remarks.para: There is not really any point in setting this value to "false". For this reason, it may be removed and set to "true" internally in some future version of SNAP.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.String.IsSecret
member.summary: if true, characters typed will be displayed as asterisks(*).

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.HighQualityBitmap
member.summary: If true, indicates that a high-quality (24-bit) version of the Bitmap should be displayed

remarks.para: This property is relevant only when the Bitmap property uses the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap. If you use a bitmap file, instead, then this property has no effect.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.Localize
member.summary: If true, indicates that the Label string should be replaced by a localized version

remarks.para: If the Label string matches an English string in the NX string localization database and the Localize property is "true", then the Label string is translated to the current locale language.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.ToolTip
member.summary: The tooltip text to be displayed when the user hovers the mouse pointer over the block

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.BalloonTooltipText
member.summary: The text to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: You can specify multiple lines of text by using "\n" to indicate new-lines.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.BalloonTooltipImage
member.summary: The pathname of the image file to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Button.BalloonTooltipLayout
member.summary: The location of the text with respect to the image in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:
Horizontal -- This is the default value. The text is placed to the right of the image.
Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.ShowMoveUpDownButtons
member.summary: If true, indicates that Up/Down buttons should be displayed

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.ListItems
member.summary: The list of items (strings) displayed in the list box

remarks.para: Note that the user can modify the contents of the list by using the Add and Delete, and can also re-order the items.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.ResizeHeightWithDialog
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block will resize as the dialog is resized

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.Height
member.summary: The number of items shown in the List Box

remarks.para: A value less than or equal to zero means that the default height will be used.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.MinimumHeight
member.summary: Specifies the minimum number of rows shown on the dialog as it is resized

remarks.para: This property is valid only if ResizeHeightWithDialog is true.
It can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.MaximumHeight
member.summary: Specifies the maximum number of rows shown on the dialog as it is resized

remarks.para: This property is valid only if ResizeHeightWithDialog is true.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.MaximumStringLength
member.summary: The maximum number of characters per row/item
member.remarks: A value less than or equal to zero means that there is no maximum.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.IsAddButtonSensitive
member.summary: If true, indicates that the "Add" button is sensitive (not grayed out)

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.IsDeleteButtonSensitive
member.summary: If true, indicates that the "Delete" button is sensitive (not grayed out)

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ListBox.SelectedItems
member.summary: The indices of the selected items (zero-based)

remarks.para: The indices are zero-based. So, if SelectedItems = {0, 2, 3}, this means that the user chose the first, third, and fourth items in the list box.
Note that the user can modify the list of items by using the Add, Delete, and Up/Down buttons on the dialog. These indices refer to the current modified list, not the original one.

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker
member.summary: Allows the user to specify colors (color indices, actually)

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.Label
member.summary: Explanatory text to label this block on the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.Enabled
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be sensitive (not grayed out) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.Expanded
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be expanded (not collapsed) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.BeginGroup
member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

remarks.para: The new group will contain the current block and any subsequent ones that have BeginGroup = False.
The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. Please see the documentation for the Group block for further information.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.RetainValue
member.summary: If true, indicates that the values in the block should be retained from one use of the dialog to the next

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.Localize
member.summary: If true, indicates that the Label string should be replaced by a localized version

remarks.para: If the Label string matches an English string in the NX string localization database and the Localize property is "true", then the Label string is translated to the current locale language.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.NumberSelectable
member.summary: The number of colors the user will be allowed to select

remarks.para: The user can select several colors by holding down the Control key. This property determines how many colors can be selected.
Note that this property and the ColorIndices property are related. Specifically, NumberSelectable must be at least as large as the number of items in the ColorIndices array.
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.ColorIndices
member.summary: The indices of the selected colors

remarks.para: Each color index is an integer in the range 1 to 216 (inclusive).
To obtain the corresponding System.Drawing.Color, you can call the Snap.Color.WindowsColor function.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.ColorIndex
member.summary: The index of the selected color (when only one is selected)

remarks.para: ColorIndex is identical to ColorIndices(0).

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.BalloonTooltipText
member.summary: The text to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: You can specify multiple lines of text by using "\n" to indicate new-lines.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.BalloonTooltipImage
member.summary: The pathname of the image file to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.ColorPicker.BalloonTooltipLayout
member.summary: The location of the text with respect to the image in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:
Horizontal -- This is the default value. The text is placed to the right of the image.
Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.LabelVisibility
member.summary: If true, indicates that the label of the block should be displayed

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.PresentationStyle
member.summary: The presentation style of the block (how it is displayed)

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.PageIncrement
member.summary: The increment/decrement when the user presses the Page Up or Page Down keys on the keyboard
member.remarks: Only available when PresentationStyle is set to Scale or ScaleKeyin

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.LineIncrement
member.summary: The increment/decrement when the user presses the arrow keys on the keyboard
member.remarks: Only available when PresentationStyle is set to Scale or ScaleKeyin

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.ShowScaleValue
member.summary: If true, indicates that the value determined by the scale (slider) should be displayed

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.ScaleLimits
member.summary: If true, indicates that the scale max and min labels should be displayed

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.ScaleMinLimitLabel
member.summary: The label indicating the minimum scale limit

remarks.para: Default is the value specified in MinimumValue property. The label is only shown if ScaleLimits property is set to True.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.ScaleMaxLimitLabel
member.summary: The label indicating the maximum scale limit

remarks.para: Default is the value specified in MaximumValue property. The label is only shown if ScaleLimits property is set to True.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.AdaptiveScaleLimits
member.summary: If true, indicates that the scale should be adaptive

remarks.para: If the scale is adaptive, its limits adjust to suitably bracket the user's current input value, which makes the scale much more useful.
The scale can be adaptive when NumberPresentationStyle is equal to either Scale or ScaleKeyIn.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.Increment
member.summary: The increment/decrement when the user clicks the up/down arrow buttons on the spin control
member.remarks: Only available when PresentationStyle is set to Spin

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.WrapSpin
member.summary: If true, indicates that the values shown in the block should "wrap" when passing beyond the minimum or maximum values.
member.remarks:
This setting applies only if PresentationStyle = Spin.
Suppose the user repeatedly clicks on the "up" arrow, trying to increase the value beyond MaximumValue. The WrapSpin setting causes the following behavior:
If WrapSpin = True, the value will "wrap" and will jump to MinimumValue.
If WrapSpin = False, the value will "stick" at MaximumValue, and clicking the up arrow will have no further effect.
Analogous behavior happens at the MinimumValue end of the range, too, of course.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.MinInclusive
member.summary: If true, indicates that a value equal to MinimumValue should be accepted as valid input

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.MaxInclusive
member.summary: If true, indicates that a value equal to MaximumValue should be accepted as valid input

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.Value
member.summary: The value shown in the block, to be edited by the user

remarks.para: The block automatically checks the user's input -- an error message will be displayed if the user tries to enter a value outside the valid range specified by the MinimumValue and MaximumValue properties.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.MaximumValue
member.summary: The maximum allowed integer value

remarks.para: Any value greater than this value is invalid. A value equal to this value is valid if the MaxInclusive property is set to "true" or if PresentationStyle is set to scale or spin

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.MinimumValue
member.summary: The minimum allowed integer value

remarks.para: Any value less than this value is invalid. A value equal to this value is valid if the MinInclusive property is set to "true" or if PresentationStyle is set to scale or spin

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.BalloonTooltipText
member.summary: The text to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: You can specify multiple lines of text by using "\n" to indicate new-lines.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.BalloonTooltipImage
member.summary: The pathname of the image file to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.BalloonTooltipLayout
member.summary: The location of the text with respect to the image in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:
Horizontal -- This is the default value. The text is placed to the right of the image.
Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Integer.ReadOnly
member.summary: If true, indicates that the value shown in the block is not editable
member.remarks: This property only takes effect when the PresentationStyle of the block is KeyIn

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.Expression
member.summary: Allows the user to enter/edit an Expression

remarks.para: The expression can be one that already exists in the part, or a new one that is created on-the-fly.
This block allows the user to type a number, just like the Double block, but it also provides access to Measurements, the Expression Editor and the Insert Function command.

member.summary: Explanatory text to label this block on the dialog

member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be sensitive (not grayed out) in the dialog

member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

member.summary: The value shown in the block, to be edited by the user

member.summary: If true, indicates that a scale (a slider bar) should be displayed

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Expression.Dimensionality
member.summary: The dimensionality of the expression (e.g. Length, Angle, Mass)

remarks.para: This determines the set of units options that are available for the quantity (e.g. for mm or in for Length, degrees or radians for Angle, etc).
This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Expression.HasUnitsMenu
member.summary: If true, indicates that a menu will be displayed allowing the user to change units

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.Expression.Formula
member.summary: Textual representation of the right-hand-side of the expression

remarks.para: This property is just a "shortcut" to ExpressionObject.RightHandSide. So, you can not use this property until the ExpressionObject property has been properly set.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.OnPathDimension.OptionMask
member.summary: Determines which of the LocationOption choices should be available to the user

remarks.para:
The option mask is specified as a sum of integers. The individual integer values are:
= 1 : by arclength
= 2 : by percentage arclength (a number between 0 and 100)
= 4 : by parameter percentage (a number between 0 and 100)
= 8 : by a point (which is projected onto the path)
So, if you want the arclength and percentage arclength options to be available, you should specify a value of 1 + 2 = 3. A value of 15 will make all four options available.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.OnPathDimension.LocationOption
member.summary: Specifies the type of technique used to locate the handle on the path.

remarks.para:
The options are:
= 0 : by arclength
= 1 : by percentage arclength (a number between 0 and 100)
= 2 : by parameter percentage (a number between 0 and 100)
= 3 : by a point (which is projected onto the path)

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.Group
member.summary: A collection of other blocks

remarks.para: The create a new group, set the BeginGroup property of its first block to True. The new group will contain the current block and any subsequent ones that have BeginGroup = False.

The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. On a BlockForm, setting BeginGroup = True will add the current block to a new group, but not subsequent ones, so the result will be a group containing a single block. If you want to create a dialog having a Group with multiple members, please use a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, rather than a BlockForm.

If you want a standalone selection dialog, rather than a selection block on a dialog, please use a Snap.UI.Selection object and the Snap.UI.Selection.SelectObject functions.

member.example:

member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be expanded (not collapsed) in the dialog

member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. Please see the documentation for the Group block for further information.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.StepStatus
member.summary: Indicates whether a selection is required in order for OK and Apply to become available

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.Cue
member.summary: Text to be displayed in the cue line. Accepts any text string.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.AllowMultiple
member.summary: If true, indicates selection of multiple objects is allowed

remarks.para: If set to false, only a single object can be selected at a time, and the focus then moves to the next block on the dialog if the AutomaticProgression property is True. If set to true, multiple objects can be selected using rectangular or lasso selection, in addition to single selection. In case of rectangular or lasso selection, the focus remains on this block until focus is shifted manually to another block. In other words, this option doesn't honor the AutomaticProgression property if objects are selected using rectangular or lasso selection

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

member.summary: The mask triples defining the selection filter

remarks.para: The integer value is a Hexadecimal representation of the Bits option. Integer values are generated in the code template. The options specified in SnapPointTypesOnByDefault must be a subset of those specified by SnapPointTypesEnabled.

remarks.para:

Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.CreateInterpartLink
member.summary: The state of the "Create Interpart Link" toggle on the Selection Bar

remarks.para: Note that this toggle is only sensitive when working in-context and the InterpartSelection property is set to "Controlled" (InterPartSelectionCopy.Controlled).

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.InterpartSelection
member.summary: Specifies the behavior of the block when selecting geometry outside of the work part

remarks.para: Setting this property will allow the block to create on-the-fly copies in the work part of the selected geometry. These copies may be either associative or non-associative.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.AutomaticProgression
member.summary: If true, indicates that focus should automatically progress to the next block

remarks.para: The blocks in a dialog are ordered in a "focus pathway". If AutomaticProgression is set to "true", then focus will automatically move to the next block in this pathway after the required steps have been completed in this one. For example, in the Unite command, when a body has been selected for the target, input selection focus automatically progresses to the tool input. If an input is the last input in the pathway, then automatic progression should be set to "false", since there is no logical next step in the pathway.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.SelectedObjects
member.summary: Array of NX objects selected by the user

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectObject.PickPoint
member.summary: The "pick point" on the selected object

remarks.para: The "pick point" is a point on the selected object. It is either the place where the cursor ray pierces the object, or the closest point of the object to the cursor ray. Please see chapter 15 of the SNAP Getting Started Guide for an explanation of the cursor ray.

member.example: This example shows how to set the filter with given face types:

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder
member.summary: Provides access to the Section Builder subfunction

remarks.para: This block allows the user to select a collection of curves using Selection Intent (SI) rules. The flow direction of the section can be reversed either by clicking the Reverse Direction button on the dialog, or by double-clicking on the direction handle in the graphics window.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.Enabled
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be sensitive (not grayed out) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.Expanded
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be expanded (not collapsed) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.BeginGroup
member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

remarks.para: The new group will contain the current block and any subsequent ones that have BeginGroup = False.
The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. Please see the documentation for the Group block for further information.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.StepStatus
member.summary: Indicates whether a selection is required in order for OK and Apply to become available

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.Cue
member.summary: Text to be displayed in the cue line. Accepts any text string.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.Bitmap
member.summary: The name of a bitmap image used to label this block

remarks.para: The name may be either the pathname of a bitmap file, like "C:\images\pic.bmp", or the name of a built-in NX icon bitmap, such as "cone". If you use a bitmap file, it must be in the bmp format.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.PointOverlay
member.summary: If true, allows the user to specify points on-the-fly, which will be added to the selection list
member.remarks: This is done by providing access to the SNAP Point toolbar and the Point Constructor dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.SnapPointTypesEnabled
member.summary: The list of snapping options that will be selected (enabled by default) on the snap point toolbar

remarks.para: See SpecifyPoint for more info

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.SnapPointTypesOnByDefault
member.summary: The list of snapping options that will be selected (enabled by default) on the snap point toolbar

remarks.para: See SpecifyPoint for more info

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.SnapPointStates
member.summary: The list of Snap Point options that will be available on the snap point toolbar

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.LabelString
member.summary: Text displayed before the object count on the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.ToolTip
member.summary: The tooltip text to be displayed when the user hovers the mouse pointer over the block

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.BalloonTooltipText
member.summary: The text to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: You can specify multiple lines of text by using "\n" to indicate new-lines.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.BalloonTooltipImage
member.summary: The pathname of the image file to be displayed in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.BalloonTooltipLayout
member.summary: The location of the text with respect to the image in the balloon tooltip

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:
Horizontal -- This is the default value. The text is placed to the right of the image.
Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.CreateInterpartLink
member.summary: The state of the "Create Interpart Link" toggle on the Selection Bar

remarks.para: Note that this toggle is only sensitive when working in-context and the InterpartSelection property is set to "Controlled" (InterPartSelectionCopy.Controlled).

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.InterpartSelection
member.summary: Specifies the behavior of the block when selecting geometry outside of the work part

remarks.para: Setting this property will allow the block to create on-the-fly copies in the work part of the selected geometry. These copies may be either associative or non-associative.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.AutomaticProgression
member.summary: If true, indicates that focus should automatically progress to the next block

remarks.para: The blocks in a dialog are ordered in a "focus pathway". If AutomaticProgression is set to "true", then focus will automatically move to the next block in this pathway after the required steps have been completed in this one. For example, in the Unite command, when a body has been selected for the target, input selection focus automatically progresses to the tool input. If an input is the last input in the pathway, then automatic progression should be set to "false", since there is no logical next step in the pathway.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.EntityType
member.summary: Specifies the entity type(s) that will be allowed for selection

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
AllowEdgesandCurves = (1 << 2) = 2^2 = 4
AllowPoints = (1 << 3) = 2^3 = 8
So, for example, if you want faces and bodies to be selectable, you should set EntityType = 16 + 64 = 80.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.CurveRules
member.summary: A bit-mask indicating which Selection Intent options should be shown on the Selection Bar.

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
SingleCurve = (1 << 0) = 1
ConnectedCurves = (1 << 1) = 2
TangentCurves = (1 << 2) = 4
FaceEdges = (1 << 3) = 8
BodyEdges = (1 << 4) = 16
SheetEdges = (1 << 5) = 32
FeatureCurves = (1 << 6) = 64
InferCurves = (1 << 7) = 128
RegionBoundaryCurves = (1 << 11) = 2048
CurvesinGroup = (1 << 12) = 4096
OuterEdgesofFaces = (1 << 13) = 8192
RibTopFaceEdges = (1 << 14) = 2^14
So, if you want to enable the SingleCurve and BodyEdges options, you should set CurveRules = 1 + 16 = 17.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.DefaultCurveRules
member.summary: The Selection Intent option that will be pre-selected

remarks.para: The integer value is one of the ones listed in the FaceRules property. So, for example, if you want the "Body Faces" option to be the default, you should set DefaultFaceRules = 16.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.StopAtIntersection
member.summary: The "Stop at Intersection" selection intent option on the Selection Bar.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.FollowFillet
member.summary: The "Follow Fillet" selection intent option on the Selection Bar.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.ChainWithinFeature
member.summary: The "Chain Within Feature" selection intent option on the Selection Bar.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.AllowStopAtIntersectionFollowFillet
member.summary: If true, indicates that Stop at Intersection, Follow Fillet, and Chain within Feature are visible on the selection bar.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SectionBuilder.AngularTolerance
member.summary: The angular tolerance value used in constructing the section

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.summary: If true, indicates that the user can change the origin curve and flow direction

member.summary: Array of NX objects selected by the user

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector
member.summary: Allows the user to select a collection of curves via Selection Intent

remarks.para: Curve selection intent is used in this block, but it does not support the SI rule options Stop at Intersection, Follow Fillet, Chain Between, and Chain within Feature.
This block is commonly employed when edges but not curves are being selected.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.Enabled
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be sensitive (not grayed out) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.Expanded
member.summary: If true, indicates that this block should be expanded (not collapsed) in the dialog

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.BeginGroup
member.summary: If true, indicates that a new group should be created to hold this block

remarks.para: The new group will contain the current block and any subsequent ones that have BeginGroup = False.
The BeginGroup property is not fully supported for blocks on a Snap.UI.BlockForm. Please see the documentation for the Group block for further information.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.StepStatus
member.summary: Indicates whether a selection is required in order for OK and Apply to become available

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.Cue
member.summary: Text to be displayed in the cue line. Accepts any text string.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.AllowMultiple
member.summary: If true, indicates selection of multiple objects is allowed

remarks.para: If set to false, only a single object can be selected at a time, and the focus then moves to the next block on the dialog if the AutomaticProgression property is True. If set to true, multiple objects can be selected using rectangular or lasso selection, in addition to single selection. In case of rectangular or lasso selection, the focus remains on this block until focus is shifted manually to another block. In other words, this option doesn't honor the AutomaticProgression property if objects are selected using rectangular or lasso selection

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.AutomaticProgression
member.summary: If true, indicates that focus should automatically progress to the next block

remarks.para: The blocks in a dialog are ordered in a "focus pathway". If AutomaticProgression is set to "true", then focus will automatically move to the next block in this pathway after the required steps have been completed in this one. For example, in the Unite command, when a body has been selected for the target, input selection focus automatically progresses to the tool input. If an input is the last input in the pathway, then automatic progression should be set to "false", since there is no logical next step in the pathway.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.SelectedObjects
member.summary: Array of NX objects selected by the user

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.EntityType
member.summary: Specifies the entity type(s) that will be allowed for selection

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
AllowEdges = (1 << 0) = 2^0 = 1
AllowCurves = (1 << 2) = 2^2 = 4
AllowPoints = (1 << 3) = 2^3 = 8
AllowFaces = (1 << 4) = 2^4 = 16
AllowBodies = (1 << 6) = 2^6 = 64
So, for example, if you want faces and bodies to be selectable, you should set EntityType = 16 + 64 = 80.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.CurveRules
member.summary: A bit-mask indicating which Selection Intent options should be shown on the Selection Bar.

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
SingleCurve = (1 << 0) = 1
ConnectedCurves = (1 << 1) = 2
TangentCurves = (1 << 2) = 4
FaceEdges = (1 << 3) = 8
BodyEdges = (1 << 4) = 16
SheetEdges = (1 << 5) = 32
FeatureCurves = (1 << 6) = 64
VertexEdges = (1 << 8) = 256
VertexTangentEdges = (1 << 9) = 512
RegionBoundaryCurves = (1 << 11) = 2048
OuterEdgesofFaces = (1 << 13) = 8192
RibTopFaceEdges = (1 << 14) = 2^14

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.CurveCollector.DefaultCurveRules
member.summary: The Selection Intent option that will be pre-selected

remarks.para: The integer value is one of the ones listed in the CurveRules property. So, for example, if you want the "Tangent Curves" option to be the default, you should set DefaultCurveRules = 4.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.FaceCollector.AutomaticProgression
member.summary: If true, indicates that focus should automatically progress to the next block

remarks.para: The blocks in a dialog are ordered in a "focus pathway". If AutomaticProgression is set to "true", then focus will automatically move to the next block in this pathway after the required steps have been completed in this one. For example, in the Unite command, when a body has been selected for the target, input selection focus automatically progresses to the tool input. If an input is the last input in the pathway, then automatic progression should be set to "false", since there is no logical next step in the pathway.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.FaceCollector.SelectedObjects
member.summary: Array of NX objects selected by the user

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.FaceCollector.EntityType
member.summary: Specifies the entity type(s) that will be allowed for selection

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
AllowFaces = (1 << 4) = 2^4 = 16 = 0x10
AllowDatums = (1 << 5) = 2^5 = 32 = 0x20
AllowBodies = (1 << 6) = 2^6 = 64 = 0x40
So, for example, if you want faces and bodies to be selectable, you should set EntityType = 16 + 64 = 80.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.FaceCollector.FaceRules
member.summary: A bit-mask indicating which Selection Intent options should be shown on the Selection Bar.

remarks.para:
The integer value is a bit-mask. The i-th bit in the integer indicates whether or not the i-th option is available. The integer value can be constructed by adding together the integer values for individual options, which are as follows:
SingleFace = (1 << 0) = 1
RegionFaces = (1 << 1) = 2
TangentFaces = (1 << 2) = 4
TangentRegionFaces = (1 << 3) = 8
BodyFaces = (1 << 4) = 16
FeatureFaces = (1 << 5) = 32
AdjacentFaces = (1 << 6) = 64
ConnectedBlendFaces = (1 << 7) = 128
AllBlendFaces = (1 << 8) = 256
RibFaces = (1 << 9) = 512
SlotFaces = (1 << 10) = 1024
BossandPocketFaces = (1 << 11) = 2048
MergedRibFaces = (1 << 12) = 4096
RegionBoundaryFaces = (1 << 13) = 8192
FaceandAdjacentFaces = (1 << 14) = 2^14

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.FaceCollector.DefaultFaceRules
member.summary: The Selection Intent option that will be pre-selected

remarks.para: The integer value is one of the ones listed in the FaceRules property. So, for example, if you want the "Body Faces" option to be the default, you should set DefaultFaceRules = 16.

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectFeature.Cue
member.summary: Text to be displayed in the cue line. Accepts any text string.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SelectFeature.AllowMultiple
member.summary: If true, indicates selection of multiple objects is allowed

remarks.para: If set to false, only a single object can be selected at a time, and the focus then moves to the next block on the dialog if the AutomaticProgression property is True. If set to true, multiple objects can be selected using rectangular or lasso selection, in addition to single selection. In case of rectangular or lasso selection, the focus remains on this block until focus is shifted manually to another block. In other words, this option doesn't honor the AutomaticProgression property if objects are selected using rectangular or lasso selection

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyPoint.SnapPointTypesEnabled
member.summary: Specifies the list of snapping options that will be available on the snap point toolbar

remarks.para: You will probably find it much easier to use the SnapPointStates property, rather than this one.

The integer value is a bit-mask representation of the options that are in the "shown" state (enabled). If the i-th bit of the integer is set to 1, this means that the i-th snap option is in the "shown" state.
Since there are 17 snap options, only the least significant 17 bits of the integer are used. If all options are selected, the integer's bits will consist of 17 ones, which means that the integer value will be 2^(17) - 1 = 131071. So, any set of options can be represented by an integer that is less than or equal to 131071.
The integer value returned by getting this property value will be at most 131071.
When setting this property, if the input value is larger than 131071, only the low-order 17 bits will be used.
The options specified in SnapPointTypesOnByDefault should be a subset of those specified by SnapPointTypesEnabled, but there is nothing here to enforce this.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyPoint.SnapPointTypesOnByDefault
member.summary: The list of snapping options that will be selected (enabled by default) on the snap point toolbar

remarks.para: You will probably find it much easier to use the SnapPointStates property, rather than this one.

The integer value is a bit-mask representation of the options that are in the "selected" state (enabled by default). If the i-th bit of the integer is set to 1, this means that the i-th snap option is in the "selected" state.
Since there are 17 snap options, only the least significant 17 bits of the integer are used. If all options are selected, the integer's bits will consist of 17 ones, which means that the integer value will be 2^(17) - 1 = 131071. So, any set of options can be represented by an integer that is less than or equal to 131071.
The integer value returned by getting this property value will be at most 131071.
When setting this property, if the input value is larger than 131071, only the low-order 17 bits will be used.
The options specified in SnapPointTypesOnByDefault should be a subset of those specified by SnapPointTypesEnabled, but there is nothing here to enforce this.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyPoint.SelectedObjects
member.summary: An array containing a Point object specified by the user

remarks.para: The array has only a single member, which is actually a Snap.NX.Point object. It is far more convenient to access this point using the SpecifiedPoint property.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyPoint.PrivateSelectedObjects
member.summary: An array containing a Point object specified by the user

remarks.para: The array has only a single member, which is actually a Snap.NX.Point object. It is far more convenient to access this Point using the SpecifiedObject property. This is a private version, for internal use, to avoid deprecation warnings.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyPoint.SpecifiedPoint
member.summary: A Snap.NX.Point object specified by the user

remarks.para:
You can use this property in two ways:
If you set its value in the OnShow function of your dialog, then the point you provide will serve as a default value for the SpecifyPoint block. If this default value is satisfactory, then the user may not need to modify it, so his work will be reduced.
You can get its value in your OnUpdate or OnApply event handler, and use it to construct other geometry. However, it's usually easier to use the Position property for this purpose.
If you don't provide a value in your OnShow function, a new Snap.NX.Point object will be created internally when the dialog is displayed. The enclosed NXOpen.Point object will be invisible, however.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyVector.PrivateSelectedObjects
member.summary: An array containing (indirectly) a direction object specified by the user

remarks.para: This is a private version, for internal use, to avoid deprecation warnings.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyVector.SpecifiedVector
member.summary: A direction object specified by the user

remarks.para: This is a Snap.NX.NXObject that wraps an NXOpen.Direction object. Since SNAP currently has no knowledge of these types of objects, you have to use NX/Open functions to work with them.

You can use this property in two ways:
If you set its value in the OnShow function of your dialog, then the object you provide will serve as a default value for the SpecifyVector block. If this default value is satisfactory, then the user may not need to modify it, so his work will be reduced.
You can get its value in your OnUpdate or OnApply event handler, and use it to construct other geometry. However, it's usually easier to use the Direction and Origin properties for this purpose.
If you don't provide a value in your OnShow function, a new Snap.NX.NXObject will be created internally when the dialog is displayed. The enclosed NXOpen.Direction object will be invisible, however.

You can get its value in your OnUpdate or OnApply event handler, and use it to construct other geometry. However, it's usually easier to use the Plane property for this purpose.
If you don't provide a value in your OnShow function, a new Snap.NX.NXObject will be created internally when the dialog is displayed. The enclosed NXOpen.Plane object will be invisible, however.

remarks.para: You can specify multiple lines of text by using "\n" to indicate new-lines.

remarks.para: The image file must be in one of the following formats: TIFF, PNG, GIF, JPEG, or BMP.

remarks.para:
This is applicable only when both text and image are specified. The two available options are:

Vertical -- The text is placed below the image.

member.summary: Indicates whether a selection is required in order for OK and Apply to become available

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCsys.CreateInterpartLink
member.summary: The state of the "Create Interpart Link" toggle on the Selection Bar

remarks.para: Note that this toggle is only sensitive when working in-context and the InterpartSelection property is set to "Controlled" (InterPartSelectionCopy.Controlled).

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCsys.InterpartSelection
member.summary: Specifies the behavior of the block when selecting geometry outside of the work part

remarks.para: Setting this property will allow the block to create on-the-fly copies in the work part of the selected geometry. These copies may be either associative or non-associative.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCsys.SelectedObjects
member.summary: An array containing a CoordinateSystem object specified by the user

remarks.para: The array has only a single member, which is actually a Snap.NX.CoordinateSystem object. It is far more convenient to access this object using the SpecifiedCsys property.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCsys.PrivateSelectedObjects
member.summary: An array containing a CoordinateSystem object specified by the user

remarks.para: The array has only a single member, which is actually a Snap.NX.CoordinateSystem object. It is far more convenient to access this CoordinateSystem using the SpecifiedCsys property. This is a private version, for internal use, to avoid deprecation warnings.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCsys.SpecifiedCsys
member.summary: A Snap.NX.CoordinateSystem object specified by the user

remarks.para:
You can use this property in two ways:
If you set its value in the OnShow function of your dialog, then the coordinate system object you provide will serve as a default value for the SpecifyCsys block. If this default value is satisfactory, then the user may not need to modify it, so his work will be reduced.
You can get its value in your OnUpdate or OnApply event handler, and use it to construct other geometry. However, it's usually easier to use the Origin and Orientation properties for this purpose.
If you don't provide a value in your OnShow function, a new Snap.NX.CoordinateSystem object will be created internally when the dialog is displayed. The enclosed NXOpen.CoordinateSystem object will be invisible, however.

member.summary: Indicates whether a selection is required in order for OK and Apply to become available

remarks.para: This property can not be set in the DialogShown callback of a Snap.UI.BlockDialog, nor in the OnShow function of a Snap.UI.BlockForm.

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCursorLocation.DisplayTemporaryPoint
member.summary: If true, indicates that a temporary point (asterisk "splat") will be displayed at the specified location

member.name: P:Snap.UI.Block.SpecifyCursorLocation.CursorLocation
member.summary: The specified cursor location

remarks.para: A "cursor location" is a 3D position. It is located on the Work Plane (the XC-YC plane) at a point that is "underneath" the screen cursor. In other words, it is calculated by firing a ray along the line of sight and intersecting this ray with the Work Plane. In a parallel view, the direction of the ray is along the view normal. In a perspective view, the computation is more complicated, but we again get a 3D position that appears to be "underneath" the screen cursor.

member.name: T:Snap.UI.Block.ReverseDirection
member.summary: Provides a way for the user to reverse the direction of a vector

remarks.para: This block synchronizes a "Reverse Direction" button on the dialog with an on-screen vector handle. The sense of the vector can be reversed either by clicking the button on the dialog, or by double clicking the handle in the graphics window. Typical uses are reversing a surface normal, reversing the direction of a vector, reversing the direction of a dimension, reversing the side of a plane, etc.
